question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: My learning was facilitated by the video forum and 1 weekly assignment as it allowed me to complete homework on my own time and on topics we had already discussed in class as opposed to having a flipped classroom. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I would say to do even more team-based activities but I’m not sure what we would do considering the nature of the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The groups facilitate learning by providing a group to ask questions to and also to have peers to help talk about materials with. I would also keep the group presentations because that helps develop scientific presentation skills which I have been able to apply to my other classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This has been my favorite course I have ever taken at Duke. Professor Nowicki is an incredible teacher. He is a great, interactive teacher. His lectures are entertaining and involving. I really like the way he allows us to discuss things with our group so it is not a regular lecture. Instead, it is more interactive, enjoyable, and social. I have really enjoyed my teammates and getting to know my group. I would definitely keep the group questions and discussions. I also liked the specific animal examples instead of simply talking about broad overall topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the learning environment was low-stress but high-reward. I always felt motivated to do the assigned readings and participate in class discussions, because I was always learning something new or engaging with familiar material in a novel way. I particularly enjoyed the pillbug/light exposure experiment we did and the data visualization exercise with the Amboseli Baboon Project data. I thought these were great applications of the material. Definitely keep in some shape or form!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that this course is one of the best classes I've taken at Duke and Dr. Nowicki is an extremely knowledgable and caring professor who puts his students first.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The only 8:30 worth taking. Unless you want to go into academia to research animals, I can’t say that this course is beneficial for your future goals, but just taking it for Dr. Nowicki makes this course worth it. Dr. Nowicki is the most down the earth, chill professor I’ve had, and he actually cares about teaching and getting to know students. He makes the class a comfortable and pleasant experience. Not at lot of work, but you still learn a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this class! It really helps with understanding how to read research papers and also how to think about design experiments.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a wonderful course! Enjoy and put the effort in! This class makes waking up at 8:30am so worth it (and actually enjoyable!). Your course grade will accurately reflect the effort we put in, which is so wonderful and rare for many duke classes. The exams are completely fair and if you pay attention in the class you will do well on the exams. Have a great time!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it! This course will not cause you unnecessary stress or grievance. As long as you are prepared (and the homework doesn't ask much of you) and willing to engage with the material in class, you will learn a lot, even if you already have a good grasp of natural selection or evolutionary biology. My main takeaway was that there are so many clever ways in which different animals solve a common set of evolutionary "problems" and sometimes they aren't what you'd expect. I also realized pretty quickly that I need to stop thinking so anthropologically about animals whose umvelts are clearly unlike ours.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to scientifically read papers and understand the hypothesis, figures, and findings. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to design experiments that addressed specific research questions about the mechanism of observed animal behaviors and how to test auxiliary hypothesis (and the importance of testing auxiliary hypothesis)I learned how to interpret circular statistics when it came to understanding what cues animals use to orient themselves to prey.I learned how to evaluate the results from figures in scientific papers and how to constructively criticize experimental design and results.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is really fun and dives into some cool concepts and papers regarding animal mechanisms and behavior. The work in the class is well spaced out and is not too much at all. I would highly recommend taking this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly suggest this course! It made me appreciate the diversity of animal behavior and think critically about what could be facilitating them. Prof. Nowicki really cares about student learning and the subject matter and lectures in a manner that is conducive to learning concepts in class and applying them to various animal behaviors. The coursework is not demanding which takes off a lot of pressure and facilitates a relaxing and effective learning environment. Be prepared to do group work throughout the semester, as your groups are fixed and random. There are 3 paper presentations you will need to record for the class but with effective communication and set deadlines, it is a stress-free process!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it. There are few courses at Duke that stimulate your learning and develop your understanding of certain biological fields while requiring little investment outside of the classroom. It allows you to focus on the content with a genuine interest in the subjects, rather than absorbing information for the sake of a grade. This is the perfect class to take if you enjoy learning about biology and want to develop your approach to research. Moreover, Steve Nowicki is an excellent professor and an enjoyable person to learn from. If you are impartial to the biological topics, at least take it to experience his incredibly thoughtful instruction and begin your days with an uplifting lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course! At first, the three in-class midterms and group coordination of the presentations were a bit intimidating, but they became enmeshed in the process of "learning how to do science." This made these feel more like learning opportunities than daunting components of the course. When you make comments on the group presentations, focus more on making one or two streamlined questions or comments, as I, at first, got a bit overwhelmed on what to focus on when posing a question to a team.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course does a really great job preparing you for scientific reasoning and very fairly tests the knowledge gained over the course of the class.

The instructor was also kind and provided valuable discussions and support when needed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

2. Due to the number of papers we read each week, I was able to significantly increase my ability to summarize and identify key information from scientific papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to efficiently and adequately read scientific papers from a variety of topics. Not only did we learn how to read them, but we learned how to constructively criticize the papers, evaluating them based on their reliability - do we believe the results? Additionally, we learned to think in the future - what further experiments could be done? What does it make you wonder about? I majorly expanded my definition of the senses - I once believed there were only 5, but after taking this class I know about many different ways in which humans and animals sense the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The very first day of class, Professor Johnsen had us list out as many senses as we could think of, and then let us as a class choose which senses were most interesting to us. He then compiled scientific papers and in-class demos to allow us to explore these senses. Professor Johnsen really cares about what we want to learn, and has exposed us to a whole new world of senses. Additionally, he requires that each of us lead a class discussion once throughout this semester. This allows us to refine our scientific communication skills. Finally, because it is a seminar, it allows us to build close connections with each other and the teacher, encouraging active participation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a deep understanding of sensory biology and the various mechanisms, honed my ability to critically read and analyze scientific papers, and explored various ways to expand upon the knowledge gained. I also enhanced my skills in reading scientific literature, learning to identify key findings, critique methodologies, and understand the broader implications of research studies. Lastly, through discussions and critiques, I learned how to recognize limitations in existing studies and brainstorm potential avenues for further investigation. These skills have equipped me to better understand and contribute to the field of sensory biology.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read scientific papers efficiently and effectively, as well as about the major senses – who would have thought so many exist! Another skill I learned was how to brainstorm creative extensions for neuro studies. For example, we looked at a lot of pilot case studies or those involving a single patient. It was challenging but cool to think of other experiments we could design and what limitations each had (often generalizability and sample size) and things that could be done in the future (higher resolution fMRIs rather than PETs, etc).

response_text: I really love this course. Dr. Sommer is very helpful both in class and after class. When we have question, he is always willing to answer. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Sommer is an incredibly thoughtful and organized professor who presents course content in a clear and accessible manner and encourages deep learning beyond just memorization by sharing relevant research papers and offering both high-level overviews and detailed explanations to contextualize concepts within a broader framework. I really appreciate that he shares his lecture slides and recordings, which not only support review after class but also allow students to revisit material they may have missed. Many of my teachers avoid sharing these resources, likely as a way to encourage attendance, but Dr. Sommer's lectures are so engaging and informative that students want to go to class, and being able to review content afterward only enhances the learning experience and helps me achieve a deeper understanding. I also enjoy that he incorporates a variety of learning modalities—coding, reading primary literature, exploring both historical context and detailed anatomical content—which keeps the material dynamic and intellectually stimulating. Although the use of pop quizzes would typically not seem favorable, I found the way he implements them very positive and successful in encouraging me to consistently review notes, while his flexibility in offering partial and extra credit shows his genuine commitment to student success and learning. Overall, Dr. Sommer is an amazing and thoughtful professor and his dedication to both student learning and well-being is evident in every aspect of his teaching.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the dominant and foundational stances on philosophy of science, the mind, and religion from Descartes to Gould to Chalmers. I learned the specific structures of arguments like that of Descartes' epistemology, Plantinga's rebuttal to naturalistic evolution, and Jackson's qualia argument against reductive physicalism. I was given the space to show my understanding of these stances and practice synthesizing my thoughts on the matter.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course is one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Duke. I'm a computer science major and never really got exposure to natural sciences as a whole and this class was a perfect way to be able to get that exposure. It was amazing to be able to touch on so many things such as physics, biology, computer science even from a perspective of philosophical inquiry and relating it to religion. It really gave me the skills and tools to be able to question my own views not only about science but about everything I do and really get to the bottom of whatever I'm learning or thinking about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Deconstructing complex philosophical/biological/physical arguments into palatable simple ones. I was really forced to understand the concepts underlying some of the most important questions that we as humans face, such as the reliability of our cognitive faculties. The essay prompts broke down these concepts and I'm definitely going to be breaking down complicated concepts in a similar way that the professor did for future difficult essays. 
2. Understanding of neuroscience -- I'm not a neuroscience major and so I had no prior knowledge on how the brain worked at all. Getting to hold a human brain in my own hands was really special and I thought that the level of information that we could get was varied enough that a neuroscience major would learn something and a newbie like me could as well. 
3. One of my biggest insights into the class was being truly captivated by my fellow Duke peers' intellect. Many of us came from different majors and backgrounds and every person added such an interest take to the conversations. I was truly impressed with the depth of knowledge and philosophical thinking of my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first ever philosophy class, and I would highly recommend it for anybody wanting to explore the subject. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow, this class was so much better than I anticipated. I truly enjoyed learning about the intersections between science and religion, in a way that held space for all opinions, faiths, and backgrounds. I didn't feel like one faith or perspective was pressed onto us, and I learned how to dive into my thoughts and mind and truly decide where I stood on issues. I learned how complex conversations surrounding evolution truly are through the different evolutionary theories-- I did not realize how much of evolutionary theory was not agreed upon, because in high school it seemed like Darwinian- natural selection was the main and agreed upon definition of evolution. Also, I have never taken a philosophy class before, and I am so glad I took this one, because I learned about various ancient philosophers, how to contrast their ideas, and specifically learned about their ideas of the mind and God, which I find fascinating as a Neuroscience student. Finally, we went to Prof. Len White's brain lab, and I had so much fun going in the context of this course. Looking at the biological brain, but harboring these deep questions about religion and what it means to be human in the back of my mind from our readings, was truly remarkable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical Analysis of Interdisciplinary Themes: I developed the ability to critically evaluate how neuroscience and religion intersect, particularly in understanding the neurological basis of spiritual experiences and how these are perceived in various cultural contexts.
2. Integrative Thinking: This course emphasized synthesizing diverse perspectives from scientific literature, philosophical texts, and theological frameworks to address complex questions about the human condition.
3. Effective Argumentation: I learned to craft arguments that bridge empirical evidence with abstract reasoning, enabling thoughtful discourse on topics that often evoke polarizing views, as exhibited during class seminar and long papers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
QUESTION ONE:
1. Engaging Lectures: Both the instructor's dynamic lectures and his incorporation of incredible guest lectures combined clear explanations of scientific concepts with thought-provoking questions that encouraged deeper exploration, in a non-conventional lecture format.
Discussion-Based Learning: The emphasis on open discussion allowed students to express diverse viewpoints and refine their arguments collaboratively. After each comment, the instructor maintained the ideal balance between validating his students' beliefs, further fostering an environment in which communication is valid, and also challenging them, asking follow-up questions intended with gauging their depth of analysis.
QUESTION TWO (Components to Retain):
1. Interdisciplinary Readings: Including a blend of neuroscience papers, religious texts, and philosophical essays was invaluable for a holistic learning experience. I will most definitely be re-reading my favorites of the one's he provided, like Lucretius and Plantinga. Not a single reading was short of exceedingly awe-provoking.
Interactive Class Discussions: These fostered a sense of intellectual curiosity among students, compelling me to take the class' complex commentary on the workings of the world with me everywhere I go as I continue to grapple with pressing inquiries, like the pursuit for meaning and the epistemological explanation for existence.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because we did not just read and listen to prominent philosophers and biologists and priests (etc.), but we directly contrasted their views to find nuances between theories of the world and God. It made me realize how empiricism is another school of thought, and our current world might be biased towards it. But there is something undeniably visceral about the human experience, that cannot be explained by science, at least not right now, and so there must be room for some higher power... this is a kind of conversation we would have in class! They were so engaging and interesting!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because it pushed me to think outside of my existing beliefs and really consider why I believe what I do. People in the class respectfully disagreed all the time, and Prof. Watkins created an environment where this was very allowed and accepted.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class provided the rare opportunity to discuss many difficult topics with no fear of judgment. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned about the different aspects of primate cognition. We mostly looked at that of apes, chimps, bonobos, and also humans. We covered topics such as the theory of mind, the puzzle of human cognition, phylogenetic trees, evolution, group selection, cognitive approaches, and much much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how we can use Tinbergen's four levels of analysis to help explain human cognitive evolution, grew in my reading and research skills on what studies have been published to expand on our understanding of human development, and adapted my thinking to value both the simplistic and complex mechanisms of the brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into the factors underlying the development of modern human evolution. I also learned about the field of EvAnth, which I hadn't explored previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I am an intended neuroscience major and had never really been exposed to the ideas of evanth as a discipline. I learned the evolutionary origins of humans, the role our brains played in our survival as a species, and learned the applications of evanth of the brain, and how the ideas discussed in class can be applied to current events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about HCE as a quantifiable and experimental thing, learning about human evolution by comparing to other primates, and learning how to read papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different pathways of human cognitive evolution (social, cultural, ecological), various issues surrounding cognitive research, and the cultural/behavioral practices of different primate species (especially bonobos).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about the intersection between evolutionary theories, cognition, and psychology in various primates 
2. I learned about a lot of different mindsets / approaches to investigating the causes of different phenomena, like Morgan's Canon and Tinbergen's 4 levels 
3. I gained insight about both the similarities and differences between humans and non-human primates, as well as similarities/differences among non-human primates (especially chimpanzees and bonobos)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the idea of thinking about subjects critically--open minded but skeptical, since even the theories that are proposed, do not necessarily mean that they are solid and indisputable--often, theories on human nature can have their flaws. I also learned how to read scientific papers more critically to extrapolate necessary data.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cognitive abilities and evolution in apes and humans. Self-domestication of dogs, bonos, and humans. Different intelligence theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me be more critical of studies we learn in the field of psychology, I learned the importance of thinking about the validity of studies and methods and when to question results. Another thing I learned is the importance of looking at chimpanzees and bonobos to better understand cognition in humans and other nonhuman primates. Lastly, I learned the skill of comparing across species and time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about children developing new ways of thinking, and honestly I now realize the importance of patience with younger kids. I also learned about how different we think from other primates.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Feldblum was one of the greatest professors I have ever had. He is very passionate about what he does and does his best to engage his students on a Friday afternoon class by encouraging participation as much as he can. In addition, I often had theoretical questions or things about evanth I wanted to discuss after class, and I enjoyed how he would take 10-15 minutes to talk with me about some cool further applications of the things we were learning in class. I wouldn't change pretty much anything, especially the essay assignments. I think the structure of the essay assignments was very fun, and a great way for me to make a new friend as well as get exposed to the research going on at Duke. Finally, after fluching Prof. Feldblum with my friend, I was very impressed by his commitment and passion to the discipline.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To succeed in this course, you should be familiar with both science and humanities. You'll have to parse through scientific studies, as well as read through dense humanities theories. You will also have to write a lot about both of these topics. This course can be a bit disorganized, so don't hesitate to ask the professors to clarify anything that you are confused about. They are both genuinely interested in the topic, and they try to ensure that their students are engaged and learning. Participation and group work are also a large part of this class and they make up most of your grade.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course touches on the foundations of neuroscience research and neuroimaging, with a particular focus on cognitive reserve. To understand the research, knowledge of how fMRI, EEG, MEG, and CSM were taught, as well as foundational principles like the basis of resting state fMRI and a multimodal theory of the brain. The course also delved into some linguistic theory and conversations about language and consciousness, as well as music and musicianship. A lot of the neuroscience research that we looked at was situated in the context of languaging and musicianship.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an amazing course. The workload is not too challenging, and the payoff is enormous. This is especially amazing to me because I am not a neuroscience or psych major, so all of the concepts in this class were new to me. Dr. Andrews is also an amazing professor, and she is always excited to hear what students will do and say.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A different way to conceptualize the history of psychiatry. You will see that it's not simply about treating people with mental illness. It is policing a lot of things most of the times.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to think of a different approach to neuroscience topics from a philosophical perspective. Not to look at things as onesided but rather as a broad spectrum.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about psychiatry and mental illnesses and their relationships with money, culture, and power.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think learning to think more critically about what we've been taught in our previous years of education was very helpful. I also learned the benefits of reading primary sources and making my own interpretations as opposed to just reading second hand reports. I also developed the skills of looking at psychiatry in different global contexts, not just America or even Western.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Developed reading and critical thinking skills. Learned about how historical context shapes the field of psychology.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analytical knowledge of mental health and mental illness and the ideas surrounding the other and what it means to be healthy. Critical thinking about who we prescribe the label of unhealthy and why.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me access to a lot of readings that taught me a bunch about how mental illness was viewed previously. In particular we discussed how medication like Prozac was targeted towards women previously to decrease their "irrational behavior," how asylums and in-patient treatment varied as time went on, and how the mechanisms of mental illness are still unclear to many people today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Questioning my convictions, opinions and knowledge
Work out the essence of a text
Following and participating in a discussion of interdisciplinary scope

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed new ways of thinking about the societal implications of the history of mental illness by analyzing the reading assignments given in class, which covered a wide range of topics with good depth. I also learned about how perspective changes the narrative of history through our discussions in class, and gained insight on how to interpret primary literature and apply them to theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned the complex and ever-shifting history of mental illness. 
I learned to read primary scientific texts more critically with an eye to the underlying arguments and presumptions. 
I learned to think more deeply about the larger, societal issues at play when thinking about and discussing mental illness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. Thinking historically about concepts that seem immutable; 2. Understanding the sociopolitical embeddedness of mental illnesses; 3. General knowledge about how psychiatry was formed as a discipline.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. The course taught me the importance and value of learning the how of critique. I sometimes feel graduate level classes can be overly critical without paying enough attention to the why and how of critique but this course taught me that the question of why and how are equally important to critique and I liked that we used some primary texts too.
2. I liked the design of the classes and the way the instructor taught left no room for misunderstanding of the texts. Because the first half of the class is lecture style, this made the discussion half of the class rooted in materials used in the class itself.
3. I gained a thorough understanding of the history of mental illness in a way that challenged my thinking about the topic before. Eg: I had always been critical of psychiatry but this course gave me the tools and language on why I am critical of psychiatry. It also challenged my own assumptions about psychiatry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
History of systems
General historical tracing connected to the fashioning of mental illness

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.i'm new to historical approach and i think it has been very helpful for me to learn to think about the emergence of specific diagnostic categories in relation to the professionalization of psychiatry in specific historical and cultural contexts.  
2. i've learned to ask what instrumental value a diagnostic category has and reverse engineering the image of mental illness to deduce the picture of normality at that specific time — and ask why were these norms the norms being valued 
3.i've developed more understanding of the relationship between mental illness, capitalism, and health. I've learnt more about how to critically interrogate a diagnostic category from an economic and materialist perspective 
4. how to have conversations across disciplines

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Practice and Revision - Since content is self-taught from the textbook, revising the content and honing your understanding is important when applying it to broader team-based applications. Where you are given real situations or studies to apply the knowledge.
Time Management - Since the class is TEAM-based, 80% of the content is student while 20% is the facilitation of professor and TA. Given a week to read over the chapter, apply the learning objectives, and fully understand the summation of the content is important. To apply in individual and team tests, as well as, the APP.
Summarizing - When reading the chapter, being able to summarize it and put it into your own words helps when reviewing for individual tests, midterms, and finals. The content written as notes isn't directly word for word from the textbook. Instead, it is broken down into your personal preference for learning.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

A good example was the chapter on anatomical methods of studying the brain. I have always struggled with this, and still sometimes do not fully understand the subltety of something such an MRI vs an fMRI. Thus, the course pushed me to refine my study methods to grasp these difficult ideas, such as making a comparison chart or using active recall/real-world application examples.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely take this class. It is not overly difficult, and the content is very interesting. Professor Ng has her quirks, but she seems to genuinely care about her students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think this course is great if you don't mind spending the time to learn its content outside of the classroom. I would caution that certain units tend to be harder than others, so one shouldn't expect each week to have the same amount of pre-class content in store. This comes to a fore in the midterm, which can be deceptively difficult given that the questions seem to be more difficult than on the RATs—or maybe the cumulative nature plays a sneaky role.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a team-based learning class, and everything is clear and straightforward what you need to complete for a given week. Keeping up with what needs to be done isn't overly difficult and the content is quite interesting. One thing to consider is that the exams may not meet your expectations. That is, the exam isn't that similar to the short in-class assessments. I would say focus more on the relevance and impacts rather than isolated information. However, there is some isolated information that you may need to know, and it may be difficult to know what information will appear. As Dr. Ng suggests, when preparing for example, focus on the learning objectives.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take if you are thinking about pursuing neuroscience as a major. I would even take if you are considering neuroscience but not sure. There is a lot of content, but if you put in the work, it's manageable. Class is structured into 1 lecture day and 1 application day, which is nice. Dr Ng is obviously very passionate about the subject and her lectures are always interesting.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will introduce you to a lot of different concepts in Neuroscience. It is not a huge amount of work, and has minimal exams.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is a necessary gateway to other neuroscience classes, so if you are premed or neuro just get it over with. Read the textbook very carefully. Much of the class depends on the dynamic of your group, so if it is great you will have a decent time but if not the class can be miserable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to read and know the content. A lot of the times the quizzes will ask a random obscure question that is just memorization and is not an application of knowledge. Be prepared to rely on other people. As it is a team based activity you have to do things as a team, its annoying if you like doing work on your own and do not like relying on other people. Things will take a long time, and the mid-term is just ridiculous as it covered very obscure content that most would expect would not be needed to know. Goes over a lot of content that is interesting, but it is a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think an introduction to neuroscience with a team is much better than learning it individually.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them to be prepared for the midterm and to dedicate a good amount of time to this class. It takes persevering as it can be quite frustrating when the midterm has several errors (typos, incorrect questions) and when it asks about niche details from a single slide of a lecture or a single diagram from the textbook rather than asking about overarching ideas or checking for overall understanding of main concepts. Some of the RAT quizzes at the beginning of the semester are also like this. The professor can be a bit passive-aggressive sometimes and even got mad at students for doing poorly on the exam (arguing that students clearly "didn't study/prioritize the class" although all students I knew including myself prepared rigorously for the exam).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared for a midterm that is a lot more difficult than what was tested during quizzes and what was discussed in class. The tests are really specific, so memorizing almost every sentence mentioned in the textbook is important to succeed in the class. Also, if you're not someone that likes to learn solely from the textbook, this class will not be very stimulating or enjoyable.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If a student is interested in neuroscience, I would encourage them to take the class! I feel that it is a great gateway course into the field, and offers a diverse range of topics students can explore to see what truly interests them. For instance, a student may find that they are interested in the more physical aspects of neuroscience, such as the intersection between vision and neuroscience. Other students may find a passion for using neuroscience to answer more philosophical questions, such as how our consciousness and perception of the world influences what we observe and take note of in day to day interactions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed several valuable thinking skills that enhanced my academic and practical abilities. First, I improved my note-taking techniques by identifying and organizing key points during lectures and readings, making my study sessions more efficient and focused. Additionally, I gained the ability to extract relevant information from dense academic texts, which involved discerning main ideas, analyzing supporting evidence, and synthesizing concepts to understand the material deeply. Lastly, I acquired hands-on research skills by participating in practical projects and experiments, which helped me connect theoretical knowledge to real-world applications while developing critical thinking and problem-solving abilities. These skills have supported my learning in this course and will be invaluable in future academic and professional pursuits.

response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was highly conducive to understanding and retaining the material, thanks to the thoughtful methods employed by the instructors and the course structure. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Class structure:
1. Read textbook chapter night before
2. Take quiz based mostly on memorization
3. Forget what you read
4. Repeat
Throughout the semester there aren't any checkpoints or projects that tie back the information we've been learning. I often feel that once the iRAT is over, there's no reinforcement of what was learned and there's no reason to continue to know what we learned the week before. This class could benefit from more in-class activities that reinforce previous material and require us to recall what we learned before so that it doesn't get forgotten and lost immediately.The iRATs themselves are also not very stimulating because they are mostly based on memorization and don't usually require a great understanding of the material. I think is partly due to the fact that our only knowledge of the subject comes from reading a textbook. A better structure might be to have us read before Tuesday, then do APP's or Labs then conclude the week with iRATs to ensure that we comprehended what we did that week.

You also have to be ok with risking the fact that you will not always be right when you speak in your group.

response_text: This course serves as a great gateway into neuroscience and is particularly beneficial for students who are exploring whether to major or minor in the field. I would definitely recommend it to anyone curious about neuroscience, as it provides a solid introduction without being overly stressful. However, it's important to note that this class has a strong self-directed learning component. If you're someone who thrives in a structured, guided environment, this may not be the best fit. But if you're comfortable teaching yourself and staying on top of the material independently, this course can be a rewarding and insightful experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The content can be a little challenging because there's so much to learn, it's so complex, and it was a little out of my comfort zone. We focused on a different topic in the textbook every week so some weeks are harder or easier than others (for ex, the week on vision was hard but the week on stress was a lot more chill). Weekly work requires reading the textbook module and preparing for the iRAT each Tuesday. You don't have to really study for the iRAT if you take good notes while reading the textbook/watching the assigned video. Quizzes are easy to do well on (simple MCQ) and they curve them - you can get up to 3 questions wrong and still get a grade of 15/15. Overall, the class is not bad and it's not difficult to do well as long as you do your work.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I grew my skills in working with a team (collaboration and communication), reading comprehension, and critical thinking. Due to the team-based nature of this class, I came out of my shell a bit and learned how to better communicate my ideas and thoughts on material with others. Through the textbook readings and iRATs, I developed the skill of reading comprehension, finding new ways to study to fully understand the material and recall it better. By reading research articles, specifically in the final presentation (where we analyzed one research article) I learned how to think critically about a study and evaluate someone else's scientific work as well as determine the implications of it.

response_text: Take advantage of the opportunity to develop team-based skills. They were truly helpful to me, and this was my favorite aspect of the course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this class to a student in the future! Professor Ng is extremely welcoming and clearly very passionate about the material. She makes an obvious effort to make sure the class is an inclusive space for everyone to find their voice and have the opportunity to engage with material and share their ideas. Although the weekly quizzes can feel a bit much at times, the course structure is really great for holding everyone accountable for keeping up with the readings on weekly basis. I also found the team aspect of the class to be a great shift from what I have experienced in every other course I've taken. With that being said, I do want to acknowledge that because EVERYTHING in this class is done with your team, the people on it can make or break your experience - I got really lucky.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should be responsible for your own learning and knowledge you gain from this course. Always read the the texbook chapters thoroughly and take/review your notes, and look up videos and resources to clarify content in the textbook that is hard to understand or challenging.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of how our brain controls virtually all of our actions, experiences, and sensations. From what we see, to what we feel, and even to what we choose to do. One specific thing I learned is how neurotransmitters and synapses function together to create inhibitory and excitatory effects that form the many sensations we feel as we are stimulated by something throughout our days. Another thing I learned   are the several methods, invasive and non-invasive, for studying brain-behavior relationships, which were really fascinating because it provides definitive evidence of how our brain impacts what we do. Finally, I also learned how different chemicals regulates wakefulness and sleep as well as how analyzing our brain waves provides more information as to what our sleep stages look like.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the basics of neuroscience and how the human brain receives and processes information. It was very engaging and real world in terms of what we explored. I really enjoyed the topic on the different neurotransmitters.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Even though they were stressful and required a lot of time outside of class to learn the material each week, discussing and revisiting the topics with teammates during class was more engaging than simply sitting and listening to the instructor.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is easy if you put in time and effort. The weekly quizzes are not hard if you do the textbook reading and watch the lecture videos. Other than that, although the material is interesting, the class and the professors do nothing to make the class engaging and stimulating. This class hasn't caused me any immense grief and I should do very well in the course, though it has felt like a waste of time.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course had lots of valuable content and is definitely worth taking if you are considering a career or degree in neuroscience, but it is almost entirely based on self motivation. There is no way to pass the class without keeping up with online lectures because the class time is not used to learn content.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: A very cool part of this class is it's unique structure. It is a team-based class. There are multiple teams of 6 people and the whole premise of the class is to encourage learning by engaging and working together, accessing the "social brain"- one of the things we learned about. It is very interesting because almost every week, we have a quiz that is taken in 2 forms. The iRAT (individual quiz) is one you take by yourself and is graded so that if you get more than 80% you will get a 100%. Then, the tRAT (team quiz) same quiz just doing it with your team while discussing potential answers and answering together. This one is fully graded on accuracy. This aspect of the class really does make it interesting and it helps develop communication and collaborative skills as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Build good relationships with your team members, that is going to be really important for the entirety of the semester. Also make sure to allot enough time to teach yourself before each iRAT (weekly quizzes) since not much is actually taught in lecture, you have to teach yourself a lot of the content.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take the class, but know most of the work is done over the weekend before the week and you have to read the textbook in order to do well on assessments. Your overall enjoyment of the class is truly based on the people in your team and if they are putting in the effort.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be prepared to have a lot of reading and memorising. Be prepared to dedicate between five-seven hours a week outside of class just to watch the lecture video, read the book, take notes, solve questions, and study for the iRATs and tRATs.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that they should be prepared to memorize a lot of detailed information relating to brain structures and processes. However, homework is minimal.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I feel that this course does not have an overwhelming workload but does require you to learn independently and on your own time. There is a textbook reading every week and 1 quiz on each reading per week.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you commit to taking notes from an in-depth reading of the textbook, the workload is manageable and only really requires work outside of class over the weekend or day before class tor read the textbook chapter(s). In class work is fun and engaging, but ensuring that your group dynamic is one of equal collaboration is vital to the success of the group.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is worth taking if you need to fulfill a prerequisite. The team based component definitely is a plus. Since the study of neuroscience is ongoing, many of the questions will often have unclear answers which can lead to ambiguity. This can be fine, but often leads to Professor Ng being extremely unclear about the true processes of the brain and body.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is a flipped classroom, so you will likely be teaching yourself. You can go to office hours for help, but most of the burden lies on you to do the reading and ensure you understand.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
I would consider this course an easy A, as long as you are committed to doing the readings every week. Outside of the readings, which usually are only about a chapter, there really is not much homework for this class. Because this class is Team Based, as long as you get a good team, you will be fine.
Also, Dr. Ng is overall a good instructor, and I feel that her assessments are fair, despite what others often say. She is definitely quirky, but she genuinely cares about the course and being a good instructor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would suggest they take it if they are interested in Neuroscience, but that it is a big commitment. I would tell them that I personally struggled learning and retaining information with the the way the curriculum is presented while acknowledging that everyone learns differently and that what doesn't work for me might work for them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's an interesting course, especially for those who love studying the brain. I was lucky with my team and they were mainly the reason why I enjoyed this class as much as I did. Most of the learning is done outside of class through readings or video lectures posted by Dr. Ng.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be actively engaged in class, and go over content in a spread out manner; it might get overwhelming if you try to cram all of the information the last couple of days. It is also very memorization-based, so this is generally a good practice to retain more information.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend that students interested in psychology/neuroscience take this course. The content is interesting, and the class is not too much work but requires lots of memorization.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I really enjoyed taking this class. The amount of content may seem overwhelming at first, but the course is very fair and Professor Overath makes the information very easy to digest and understand.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them to be ready to write a group research paper.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say that you have to take it for the neuroscience major. If you are not a neuroscience major, then I would not recommend this class to take for fun. You really have to teach the information to yourself after copying all of the notes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Great class! Reviewing slides could be tremendously helpful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a really interesting class and if you want to major in neuroscience take this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would advise that you keep up with the content regularly, as there are lots of specific details to be considered, and it can be difficult to try to learn them all at the last second.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don’t stress over the paper in discussion. In spring 2025, it was ~1,000 words. Before that first midterm, learn which studying technique works for you. Do fall back on memory encoding skills you have employed for other classes as it will only help you during moments of last-minute readings.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class has a lot of memorization. I feel like there's an expectation that you already have at least a pretty good understanding of different brain regions, which I didn't really have.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course isn't as challenging as other neuroscience courses, but it is still difficult. Course material was, personally, fun to learn, and gave a good overview of how our brain is involved in differing aspects and functions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course; it's very helpful, and I enjoyed my time in it. If possible, take NEURO 277 and NEURO 223 before this course, as they will help you prepare very well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the biological underpinnings of neuroscience, including the specifics of neurological development, equations to calculate equilibrium potentials, and variances in action potential transference.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to record roach leg action potentials, cellular and molecular neurobiology research techniques and mechanisms, and how to effectively read scientific papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The ability to critically analyze the components of research papers, participate in effective team-based communication, and to apply knowledge of biological processes to the real world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I feel I really learned a lot about the cellular and molecular biology of the brain, including a very detailed understanding of action potentials and how signaling in the brain works. I also learned how to read, understand, and work with a variety of scientific texts and research articles. I learned how to analyze complex figures and graphs.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A method I learned in this course was about general academia: studying right after a lecture. This is only because of how fast-paced the course was, which forced me to study in between Monday lectures and Wednesday quizzes (which were a huge chunk of our grade). Three specific things I learned include the ways in which neurons communicate via firing, the chemical basis for this, and also the cellular mechanisms for things like sensory abilities, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned many fundamental concepts of cell biology, and ways to think about not only neurons, but the entire body.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to be independent with the coursework since there was so much material to understand within a short period of time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the methods neuroscientists use to make conclusions about neurobiology from monosynaptic tracing through modified rabies to planting channel rhodopsin from algae into the brains of mice. I learned about the main structures that make up the fundamental parts of neuroscience: the axon, dendrites, soma, and types of neurotransmitters. I also learned about the mechanisms for their function: ion transport, actin polymerization, transduction, etcetc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How neuronal signaling works, including the different types of receptors and internal signaling pathways that are enacted by different neurotransmitters. 
How sensation occurs on a cellular and molecular level, including somatosensation, chemical sensation, and specialized sensation pathways such as vision and audition. 
The development on the nervous system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors and the course structure both promoted low-stakes practice, since we had a routine for the kinds of activities we'd do (lecture on Monday, short quiz on Wednesday, applied activity on Friday) and we'd complete almost all activities with a team. It made it easy to plan for and prepare for the class, and made small mistakes less significant.The instructors, including the Professor and the TA, made neuroscience very approachable, teaching to all backgrounds while still getting through an in-depth and impressive neurobiology curriculum. This was my second neuroscience class ever, but I felt like I learned more and was more confident than I would be even in subjects where I've taken more classes, because the Professor gave everyone a clear path to understanding the content and TAs were available to answer questions whenever needed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Before Neuro223, I have never been in a class where I could look at the slides in awe and feel so amazed by how incredibly complex the nervous system is, and especially how humans have designed such innovative methods to investigate the nervous system. I would say that Neuro223 has been the most worthwhile class I've taken at Duke and definitely my favorite. As a neuroscience major, taking Neuro223 felt like I finally was learning what I came to Duke to learn. Dr. Newpher is an amazing professor, and I would highly, highly suggest taking Neuro223 with him. His enthusiasm for both teaching and neuroscience shows through his compassionate help. 
I would say this course is slightly difficult (definitely more difficult than Neuro102). Most topics are not challenging to understand, but the extent to which we are expected to understand some concepts is quite detailed. Thus, I would highly suggest having a working understanding of biology, chemistry, and physics before taking this class, since these concepts are fundamental to the class, such as understanding how ions establish the electrochemical gradient and how current and voltage are related. Additionally, I would say that it's not necessary to read the textbook for this class, as Newpher tests only based off his slideshows, and the textbook includes many unnecessary details.

response_text: Do not take this course until you have finished the Bio gateway courses, specifically Bio 201. I know it's just listed as a recommended prerequisite, but having a strong fundamental grasp of molecular bio is critical to do well in this course otherwise you'll constantly play catch-up. Dr. Volkan won't go into detail about concepts from Bio 201 that you should already know because there's a lot of content to cover in this course. However, definitely take this course whether you're a bio or neuro major!! Up to date, I've never learned so much in one course at Duke as I have in this one. Don't get behind, keep up with the studying in bits because there's weekly quizzes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is important to develop a foundation in neuroscience and biology, however the quizzes are pretty tough and it is best if you stay on top of the lecture material each week and plan ahead for the quizzes.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned a lot of the different parts of development in the brain on a molecular level, such as synaptogenesis, axon guidance, etc. I also learned of how many of the basic physiological/somatosensory modalities function, such as olfaction, gustation, and the visual system.

Three specific things I learned include olfactory, auditory, mechanosensory, gustatory, and visual systems, cytoskeletal role and function, and axon guidance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
