question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

It was also interesting to learn about how highly organized many of the systems we take for granted are and it's exciting to learn that type of stuff!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a variety of neurological techniques including in-situ hybridization, RNA-blocking, immunohistochemistry, and heterologous systems. I also learned about the inner-workings of sensory systems including temperature detection, olfactory, and auditory systems. I also learned a lot about how scientists work to understanding the connectomes of a variety of organisms in order to better comprehend the complex networks of the nervous system.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through NEUROSCI-223, I developed a strong foundation in understanding molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying neural development and signaling. First, I learned how specific molecular pathways (such as Notch-Delta signaling) regulate neurogenesis and neural patterning. Second, I gained skills in critically evaluating primary neuroscience research articles, especially understanding experimental design and interpreting data figures. Third, I deepened my ability to synthesize complex biological systems by connecting concepts across different levels (genes, cells, circuits) and appreciating the integration of molecular biology and neuroscience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Volkan was great and clearly cared about her students. I also liked when she would have us review/discuss content with partners in class, I hope she includes more of that in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I actually really liked the format of this course, especially for context as dense as this. It's become increasingly common in the neuro department to do this "flipped classroom" thing which I think can work in lower level neuro classes but not in higher level ones where you need the expertise of a professor to teach you what's going on. It's really clear that Dr. Volkan knows what she's talking about and I generally appreciated the structure of the lectures. I also liked that the quizzes were not every single week (like other neuro classes) because it doesn't exhaust a person but it's still consistent enough assessment to minimize stress with the course.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: While controversial, I personally was a fan of having a quiz every 2-3 weeks as compared to the traditional midterm style of learning. This held me accountable for keeping up with the material rather than cramming right before an exam.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were very engaging and concepts were explained clearly. I really appreciated the detail explanations provided in the key concepts and homework keys; this really helped me understand the concepts at a deeper level! I really enjoyed being able to connect what I was learning in lecture with what I was learning in discussion. I am also really enjoying the process of writing questions as the final; I am getting really awesome opportunity to dive deeper into topics that I struggled with. I also really appreciated that the quizzes were not every week back to back; this certainly made it more effective in having ample time to digest the material and really work to understand it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Volkan created a structured yet flexible learning environment. The integration of lecture content with assigned primary research articles and figure-reading activities helped solidify the material and practice real scientific analysis. I especially appreciated the opportunities for active discussion during lectures and the clear organization of material on Sakai. I would recommend keeping the emphasis on primary literature discussion and structured review sessions for future years, as these were particularly effective.

Additionally, I really appreciate the lectures being recorded; there was a lot of information presented in this course that were not described in lecture slides, and I sometimes needed to pause and replay the video in order to fully understand complex mechanisms. Very thankful for this feature, as it was key to a lot of students' success in the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the dominant and foundational stances on philosophy of science, the mind, and religion from Descartes to Gould to Chalmers. I learned the specific structures of arguments like that of Descartes' epistemology, Plantinga's rebuttal to naturalistic evolution, and Jackson's qualia argument against reductive physicalism. I was given the space to show my understanding of these stances and practice synthesizing my thoughts on the matter.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned methods of defending philosophical statements, different ways to think about consciousness, and to consider all possible factors when examining a subject through a philosophical lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course is one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Duke. It gave me so much insight into how to think about things like science, neuroscience, biology from not only a scientific perspective but also a perspective that is focused on questioning the nature of these things. I'm a computer science major and never really got exposure to natural sciences as a whole and this class was a perfect way to be able to get that exposure. It was amazing to be able to touch on so many things such as physics, biology, computer science even from a perspective of philosophical inquiry and relating it to religion. It really gave me the skills and tools to be able to question my own views not only about science but about everything I do and really get to the bottom of whatever I'm learning or thinking about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Deconstructing complex philosophical/biological/physical arguments into palatable simple ones. I was really forced to understand the concepts underlying some of the most important questions that we as humans face, such as the reliability of our cognitive faculties. The essay prompts broke down these concepts and I'm definitely going to be breaking down complicated concepts in a similar way that the professor did for future difficult essays. 
2. Understanding of neuroscience -- I'm not a neuroscience major and so I had no prior knowledge on how the brain worked at all. Getting to hold a human brain in my own hands was really special and I thought that the level of information that we could get was varied enough that a neuroscience major would learn something and a newbie like me could as well. 
3. One of my biggest insights into the class was being truly captivated by my fellow Duke peers' intellect. Many of us came from different majors and backgrounds and every person added such an interest take to the conversations. I was truly impressed with the depth of knowledge and philosophical thinking of my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first ever philosophy class, and I would highly recommend it for anybody wanting to explore the subject. I learned how to think very deeply about some of the biggest questions, write detailed papers on philosophical arguments, and perhaps most importantly, how to ask questions and work towards the answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow, this class was so much better than I anticipated. I truly enjoyed learning about the intersections between science and religion, in a way that held space for all opinions, faiths, and backgrounds. I didn't feel like one faith or perspective was pressed onto us, and I learned how to dive into my thoughts and mind and truly decide where I stood on issues. I learned how complex conversations surrounding evolution truly are through the different evolutionary theories-- I did not realize how much of evolutionary theory was not agreed upon, because in high school it seemed like Darwinian- natural selection was the main and agreed upon definition of evolution. Also, I have never taken a philosophy class before, and I am so glad I took this one, because I learned about various ancient philosophers, how to contrast their ideas, and specifically learned about their ideas of the mind and God, which I find fascinating as a Neuroscience student. Finally, we went to Prof. Len White's brain lab, and I had so much fun going in the context of this course. Looking at the biological brain, but harboring these deep questions about religion and what it means to be human in the back of my mind from our readings, was truly remarkable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical Analysis of Interdisciplinary Themes: I developed the ability to critically evaluate how neuroscience and religion intersect, particularly in understanding the neurological basis of spiritual experiences and how these are perceived in various cultural contexts.
2. Integrative Thinking: This course emphasized synthesizing diverse perspectives from scientific literature, philosophical texts, and theological frameworks to address complex questions about the human condition.
3. Effective Argumentation: I learned to craft arguments that bridge empirical evidence with abstract reasoning, enabling thoughtful discourse on topics that often evoke polarizing views, as exhibited during class seminar and long papers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
QUESTION ONE:
1. Engaging Lectures: Both the instructor's dynamic lectures and his incorporation of incredible guest lectures combined clear explanations of scientific concepts with thought-provoking questions that encouraged deeper exploration, in a non-conventional lecture format.
Discussion-Based Learning: The emphasis on open discussion allowed students to express diverse viewpoints and refine their arguments collaboratively. After each comment, the instructor maintained the ideal balance between validating his students' beliefs, further fostering an environment in which communication is valid, and also challenging them, asking follow-up questions intended with gauging their depth of analysis.
QUESTION TWO (Components to Retain):
1. Interdisciplinary Readings: Including a blend of neuroscience papers, religious texts, and philosophical essays was invaluable for a holistic learning experience. I will most definitely be re-reading my favorites of the one's he provided, like Lucretius and Plantinga. Not a single reading was short of exceedingly awe-provoking.
Interactive Class Discussions: These fostered a sense of intellectual curiosity among students, compelling me to take the class' complex commentary on the workings of the world with me everywhere I go as I continue to grapple with pressing inquiries, like the pursuit for meaning and the epistemological explanation for existence.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class exposed us to texts that we wouldn't familiarly be exposed to, specifically as the majority of our class were science- or math-based majors.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The questions we attempted to answer in this class, reading and talking about different philosophers' views really made the class very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because we did not just read and listen to prominent philosophers and biologists and priests (etc.), but we directly contrasted their views to find nuances between theories of the world and God. It made me realize how empiricism is another school of thought, and our current world might be biased towards it. But there is something undeniably visceral about the human experience, that cannot be explained by science, at least not right now, and so there must be room for some higher power... this is a kind of conversation we would have in class! They were so engaging and interesting!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because it pushed me to think outside of my existing beliefs and really consider why I believe what I do. People in the class respectfully disagreed all the time, and Prof. Watkins created an environment where this was very allowed and accepted.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class provided the rare opportunity to discuss many difficult topics with no fear of judgment. For example, we were able to discuss evolution and natural selection, both complimenting and criticizing the theory, something I haven't been able to do in many other science courses at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of neuroscience (Aristotle, ventricular doctrine...), whether the brain can be functionally localized, lesion studies and brain function, brain area, fMRI controversies, reductionism, the brain as a computer, the Marr framework, mechanistic explanations of neuroscience, memory, consciousness, and free will among other topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
1) A lot about the history of psychology and neuroscience, how they intersected and are undergirded by philosophy, and the origins of a lot of the ideas about the brain we have today
2) To think more critically about neuroscientific methods, considering the limitations of different instruments and other methodological approaches
3) A lot more about some foundational neuroscience and psychology case studies that I have heard of but not engaged with nearly as critically as we did here

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about different lenses to look at human evolution by using Tinbergen's 4 levels of explanation. Additionally, understanding the natural fallacies that people sometimes used to combat policies or political ideologies. Lastly, the idea that evolution happened to benefit an individual and not a group was something I didn't know before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned about the different aspects of primate cognition. We mostly looked at that of apes, chimps, bonobos, and also humans. We covered topics such as the theory of mind, the puzzle of human cognition, phylogenetic trees, evolution, group selection, cognitive approaches, and much much more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how we can use Tinbergen's four levels of analysis to help explain human cognitive evolution, grew in my reading and research skills on what studies have been published to expand on our understanding of human development, and adapted my thinking to value both the simplistic and complex mechanisms of the brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of insight into the factors underlying the development of modern human evolution. I also learned about the field of EvAnth, which I hadn't explored previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I am an intended neuroscience major and had never really been exposed to the ideas of evanth as a discipline. I learned the evolutionary origins of humans, the role our brains played in our survival as a species, and learned the applications of evanth of the brain, and how the ideas discussed in class can be applied to current events.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Thinking about HCE as a quantifiable and experimental thing, learning about human evolution by comparing to other primates, and learning how to read papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the different pathways of human cognitive evolution (social, cultural, ecological), various issues surrounding cognitive research, and the cultural/behavioral practices of different primate species (especially bonobos).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned a lot about the intersection between evolutionary theories, cognition, and psychology in various primates 
2. I learned about a lot of different mindsets / approaches to investigating the causes of different phenomena, like Morgan's Canon and Tinbergen's 4 levels 
3. I gained insight about both the similarities and differences between humans and non-human primates, as well as similarities/differences among non-human primates (especially chimpanzees and bonobos)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the idea of thinking about subjects critically--open minded but skeptical, since even the theories that are proposed, do not necessarily mean that they are solid and indisputable--often, theories on human nature can have their flaws. I also learned how to read scientific papers more critically to extrapolate necessary data.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cognitive abilities and evolution in apes and humans. Self-domestication of dogs, bonos, and humans. Different intelligence theories.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course helped me be more critical of studies we learn in the field of psychology, I learned the importance of thinking about the validity of studies and methods and when to question results. Another thing I learned is the importance of looking at chimpanzees and bonobos to better understand cognition in humans and other nonhuman primates. Lastly, I learned the skill of comparing across species and time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed new ways to study. I went back to writing in my notebook and focusing on course objectives when studying for midterms. I learned about children developing new ways of thinking, and honestly I now realize the importance of patience with younger kids. I also learned about how different we think from other primates.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Cognitive evolution of humans and how we can develop insights on this by observing other animals, research methods for cognitive evolution, different theories for human cognitive evolution.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Feldblum was one of the greatest professors I have ever had. He is very passionate about what he does and does his best to engage his students on a Friday afternoon class by encouraging participation as much as he can. In addition, I often had theoretical questions or things about evanth I wanted to discuss after class, and I enjoyed how he would take 10-15 minutes to talk with me about some cool further applications of the things we were learning in class. I wouldn't change pretty much anything, especially the essay assignments. I think the structure of the essay assignments was very fun, and a great way for me to make a new friend as well as get exposed to the research going on at Duke. Finally, after fluching Prof. Feldblum with my friend, I was very impressed by his commitment and passion to the discipline.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a wide variety of topics in the fields of ethics and neuroscience. I learned about fundamental moral theories and how contemporary neuroscience research informs and complicates our understanding of agency, the penal system, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different theories of how emotion and reason contribute to ethical decision-making, I learned a lot about psychopathy, and I learned about the distinction between the ethics of neuroscience and the neuroscience of ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about various brain structures and how they relate to specific functions. I learned about how neuroscience and law interact. I learned about how consciousness is perceived and analyzed from a neuroscientifc lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ethical discussions and talking with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the neurobiological bases of psychopathy, moral judgments, and addiction.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to think philosophically and hold philosophical discourse, how to integrate multidisciplinary information, how to be scientifically literate, and how to critically analyze scientific studies.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The why by which Prof. Huettel, and Prof. Sinnott-Armstrong divided teaching time to give us more information on their areas of expertise was incredibly helpful. I also really appreciated their encouragement of class engagement.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were managable, interesting, and relevant. The May book was especially great!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussions in class were very fun and informative, I would focus on those more.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the doing discussions and debates in the beginning of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the availability of office hours and open-ended small group discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love that this course is co-taught; it adds a level of dimensionality that really makes the course great. The presentations are always interesting, and I really enjoy the inclusion of a case study and discussion questions in each class period.

response_text: The group discussions made the class very stimulating. Sometimes the length of the slide decks dragged on and made it difficult to pay attention towards the end of class though.

response_text: The instructors frequently challenged us with both philosophical questions and empirical considerations and urged us to question theories and hypotheses we encountered.

response_text: The discussions every class were quite stimulating.

response_text: loved the things they made us think about .

response_text: This class is question/discussion-focused, and the kinds of questions and the nature of overlap between neuroscience and philosophy really made me think in different ways. This was especially effective through the incorporation of case studies and examples regarding research studies. Having guest lecturers was also an amazing part of this class that provided different perspectives.

response_text: It's a very fun class that doesn't demand much work outside the classroom but is very stimulating within it.

response_text: I now have a bunch of knowledge about random animals and why they act in certain ways/what makes them unique. A framework to analyze animals behavior and come up with theories and experiments to test my ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a way of thinking that not only figured out what questions to ask in a scientific setting but also how to develop experiments to try to explain them. I also continued to develop my teamwork skills.

response_text:
Experimental design

Behavior mechanisms

response_text:
1. Synthesizing information to make predictions and design experiments about animal behavior
2. comparing and contrasting animal behaviors
3. distilling papers down to their most important points and creating an easily digestible presentation

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: -why animals think the way they do

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to craft an experiment, how to communicate science effectively, how to evaluate animal behavior without biases

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading and analyzing research papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to design experiments, understand the rationale for studies, and summarize papers

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the foundations of animal behavior, which I really did not know much about before this class. Also, I learned so much about the experimental processes that underlie these types of experiments, which gave me really important context for how researchers structure and conduct studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to come up with and evaluate scientific experiments, think about how animals become evolutionarily successful, and how animals communicate, avoid becoming food, get their food, and hormonal effects on behavior.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned behavioral mechanisms for a variety of different issues that animals must solve in order to survive. I learned how to analyze and read scientific papers. I also learned how to communicate scientific topics within a group and present topics in a audiovisual manner.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about experimental design and how to interpret data. Learned about how animals find their way, get the message across, reproduce and grow up well. Learned to effectively created concise presentations on research papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: There were 6 different themes in the course that were very well-structured and helped categorized what we learned. Examples: finding your way around, getting food, finding a mate. A skill was interpreting scientific papers and data, as well as how to design experiments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How to analyse scientific papers
The interactions of multiple factors on behaviour 
How to ask scientific questions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Presenting science to others, reading scientific papers, reading graphs

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: how to design experiments, critically read scientific articles, about animals I otherwise never would have been curious about

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- understanding behavior of animals
- connecting behavior to evolutionary meanings
- connect articles to class principles

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read scientific papers in the field of behavioral ecology, communicate results in presentation form, and work with a group to design experiments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: What is information and how do animals acquire it, how do animals navigate, how do animals communicate? Focuses on the concept of umvelten and the different perceptions of animals

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how animals get information, find a mate, and navigate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to present scientific papers that I did not write. I learned how to think about designing experiments to study animal behavior and the mechanisms behind those behaviors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the mechanisms of how animals navigate, communicate with each other, and avoid predation (to name a few).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed more skills in relation to experimental design- I learned how to consider whole world views, think outside of the box, and not be afraid of out-there ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) animals don’t see that world they way we do, so we can’t assume that when doing research
2) proximate vs ultimate
3) how to go about answering research questions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better understanding of how to read research papers and how to synthesize what they say to present findings in an efficient way. I also learned how to interpret data, especially from tables that are sometimes more outdated and I bit more difficult to understand.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I am very grateful for everything I learned in this course. I learned how to think about animal behavior in a scientific way. I learned about the different methods for testing and experimenting with animal behavior. I feel confident in every example we learned and each of the modules.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course offered a unique and holistic way of thinking about biology and how organisms behave. The course layout helps develop critical scientific thinking and covers a wide range of interesting topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think critically about conducting different experiments, I know major ideas and mechanisms about different animal behaviors, and I am able to understand and read different graphs found in many types of papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do it! This course will not cause you unnecessary stress or grievance. As long as you are prepared (and the homework doesn't ask much of you) and willing to engage with the material in class, you will learn a lot, even if you already have a good grasp of natural selection or evolutionary biology. My main takeaway was that there are so many clever ways in which different animals solve a common set of evolutionary "problems" and sometimes they aren't what you'd expect. I also realized pretty quickly that I need to stop thinking so anthropologically about animals whose umvelts are clearly unlike ours.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Umwelt - cannot impose human ways of understanding the world onto different animals - each have their own world

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to design experiments incorporating animal behavior, think critically about animal perspectives (umwelt), and better understand scientific papers and break down concepts from experiments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had read a lot about animal behavior before this course but had not had much exposure to the mechanistic side (genetic/physiological/brain underpinnings, etc.) of animal behavior. I also learned about specific case studies (animal species, interesting studies). And I learned more about HOW scientific studies are conducted and designed, which was great.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to scientifically read papers and understand the hypothesis, figures, and findings. I learned different ways in which animals obtain information and use this to eat or avoid being eaten. I learned how to present scientific papers in a format that's engaging and informative.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to design experiments that addressed specific research questions about the mechanism of observed animal behaviors and how to test auxiliary hypothesis (and the importance of testing auxiliary hypothesis)I learned how to interpret circular statistics when it came to understanding what cues animals use to orient themselves to prey.I learned how to evaluate the results from figures in scientific papers and how to constructively criticize experimental design and results.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed many ways of thinking, insights, skills, methods, and knowledge from this course. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Highly suggest this course! It made me appreciate the diversity of animal behavior and think critically about what could be facilitating them. Prof. Nowicki really cares about student learning and the subject matter and lectures in a manner that is conducive to learning concepts in class and applying them to various animal behaviors. The coursework is not demanding which takes off a lot of pressure and facilitates a relaxing and effective learning environment. Be prepared to do group work throughout the semester, as your groups are fixed and random. There are 3 paper presentations you will need to record for the class but with effective communication and set deadlines, it is a stress-free process!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it. There are few courses at Duke that stimulate your learning and develop your understanding of certain biological fields while requiring little investment outside of the classroom. It allows you to focus on the content with a genuine interest in the subjects, rather than absorbing information for the sake of a grade. This is the perfect class to take if you enjoy learning about biology and want to develop your approach to research. Moreover, Steve Nowicki is an excellent professor and an enjoyable person to learn from. If you are impartial to the biological topics, at least take it to experience his incredibly thoughtful instruction and begin your days with an uplifting lecture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

This made these feel more like learning opportunities than daunting components of the course. When you make comments on the group presentations, focus more on making one or two streamlined questions or comments, as I, at first, got a bit overwhelmed on what to focus on when posing a question to a team.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned a lot about the different circuits in the brain and I didn't realize how the parts of the brain were connected before. In particular, we learned about how the dlPFC is the hub of the corticohippocampal circuit which contributes to disorders that cause dysfunctions in executive control. They can lead to schizophrenia, substance use disorder and OCD.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about circuits in the brain that affect disorders through anatomy of the brain, what circuits represent order in the brain, and what circuits look like when there is disorder in the brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the current neuroscientific understanding of how neural circuits and processes integrate to develop order and disorder in response to threat (recognition/reaction - corticolimbic circuit), goal-directed behavior (motivation/action - corticostriatal circuit), and higher order processing (executive control/memory - corticohippocampal circuit).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) Understanding the why in regards to improper functioning of the brain.2) Understanding how circuits work.3) Understanding real life stories of cases that exhibit disordered brain behavior.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: knowledge of critical brain circuity, anatomy, and how to interpret research studies

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
(1) learned dynamics of and relational between psychopathology behavior and various brain circuits
(2) learned anatomical structures implicated in the normative and disordered brain
(3) developed a structure through which to synthesize literature on neuroscience findings

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I loved this class. I feel I have a solid understanding of the corticolimbic, corticostriatal, and corticohippocampal circuits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how various circuits in the brain function, but specifically how they overlap and connect to control behavior. I learned detailed anatomy and signaling within the amygdala and prefrontal cortex. I learned how various outward behaviors can be related to the functioning / misfunctioning of these circuits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I also learned a new method of studying that I think will benefit me throughout the rest of my time while I major in Neuroscience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Neuroanatomy, recent and applicable research studies that I wouldn't have heard about outside of the scope of this class, and being able to draw connections between anatomical circuitry in the brain and specific mental disorders.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To succeed in this course, you should be familiar with both science and humanities. You'll have to parse through scientific studies, as well as read through dense humanities theories. You will also have to write a lot about both of these topics. This course can be a bit disorganized, so don't hesitate to ask the professors to clarify anything that you are confused about. They are both genuinely interested in the topic, and they try to ensure that their students are engaged and learning. Participation and group work are also a large part of this class and they make up most of your grade.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course provided me with a deeper and more holistic understanding of the complexities involved in drug development and treatment. Professor Sawyer did an exceptional job of teaching us not just the biological mechanisms of how drugs work, but also the various biological, physiological, ethical, and societal factors that must be considered when developing and administering treatments. Her approach emphasized that the development of drugs is not just about scientific discovery but also about understanding their real-world impact, including considerations of access, safety, and patient care. This broader perspective helped me appreciate the intricate balance between efficacy and the diverse ethical and practical issues involved in drug therapies.
One of the most valuable skills I developed was the ability to research and write a comprehensive report on a drug's effectiveness, particularly in relation to a specific medical issue, such as vasculitis. I had the opportunity to explore why current treatments were ineffective and collaborate with my peers to propose novel drug solutions. This hands-on project pushed me to think critically about treatment limitations and how to improve them. The experience of designing a clinical trial for the drug was particularly enlightening. It gave me valuable insight into the complex processes of trial design, including identifying variables, ensuring patient safety, and navigating ethical concerns. This knowledge is something I would not have gained without the course and will be essential in my future as a physician.
Perhaps the most profound insight I gained was understanding how drugs affect biological processes and why certain drugs work for some patients but not for others. This realization highlighted the importance of personalized medicine, where treatment plans are tailored to the unique genetic, environmental, and physiological factors of each patient. I now appreciate that drug development and administration are not one-size-fits-all solutions. Instead, they require a humanistic and comprehensive approach that takes into account the full complexity of the patient. This way of thinking—focused on patient individuality and the variability of biological responses—will inform my approach to patient care, ensuring I treat people as whole individuals rather than as cases or conditions to be managed.

I learned about the barriers of drug design and production.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the semester-long project about designing a drug from conception to clinical trials. I liked how I was able to use my imagination, curiosity, and knowledge from previous classes to do the project. It would be really cool if I saw this drug being made in the future. I also liked the concept of the biweekly quizzes compared to larger tests, since they were more digestable. The grading and organization of the class was good in terms of number of assignments. Dr. Sawyer was also an amazing professor and was able to meet outside of class whenever I needed help with brainstorming or class content. The slides were also generally useful to review later on, and the lectures were very organized. I really liked the 3 assignments we did, especially the last one. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The structure and components of this course created an ideal learning environment that blended traditional instruction with active, collaborative learning. I particularly appreciated the balance between didactic lectures, where we were introduced to new information, and the group activities that encouraged us to engage directly with real-world problems. This dual approach allowed me to not only absorb the material but also to apply it in meaningful ways. Working on group projects, especially those addressing real-life issues, made the theoretical concepts we discussed in class feel relevant and tangible. The combination of learning new concepts and immediately using them to think critically and develop solutions was incredibly effective, solidifying my understanding in a way that simply listening to lectures could not have done.
One memorable example of this was the fun in-class activities, like the Halloween project, where we worked in teams to research a topic and present our findings to the class. This was not just an opportunity to deepen our knowledge, but also a chance to develop important skills in teamwork and public speaking. Learning to communicate complex information clearly and effectively is an essential skill in any field, and the experience of presenting to peers in a structured, supportive environment gave me a valuable opportunity to hone this skill. These interactive components, which emphasized collaboration and communication, are aspects of the course I would certainly recommend keeping in future iterations. They contributed to an engaging and dynamic classroom experience that was both intellectually stimulating and personally rewarding.
However, as effective as the course structure and activities were, it was Professor Sawyer’s teaching style and personal example that truly made the learning environment exceptional. She brought a calm, positive energy to every class, fostering an atmosphere where intellectual curiosity thrived. Her respectful and empathetic approach to teaching made me feel seen and heard, allowing me to ask questions and express doubts after class and engage deeply with the material. More than just imparting knowledge, she embodied the values of thoughtfulness, compassion, and ethical integrity. These qualities inspired me to approach learning and, ultimately, my future career with a sense of purpose and responsibility. Professor Sawyer’s influence went far beyond her role as a lecturer; she set a standard for how to teach with care, passion, and respect for students, and I believe that future students will benefit not only from the course’s content and structure but from her example as a role model.

Additionally, periodic quizzes helped me stay accountable and keep up with the material without being too stressful. The major group project of the course allowed me to apply all that I had learned in a product that demonstrated my understanding that I could feel proud of. Additionally, Dr. Sawyer was accessible both in and outside of class while we worked on our projects. She was happy to answer questions, always kindly and encouraging towards us, no matter how stupid the questions probably seemed to her.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I highly recommend it. It offers a unique and comprehensive perspective on pharmacology, covering not just the biological and physiological mechanisms of drugs, but also the ethical, societal, and personal considerations that are essential for anyone pursuing a career in healthcare. As future prescribers of medication, understanding how drugs work in the body, the limitations of current treatments, and the complexities of individualized care is vital. This course goes beyond textbook knowledge—it encourages you to think critically about real-world issues, such as why certain treatments may not work for all patients and how to design drugs and clinical trials that can address these disparities. The hands-on activities, particularly the group projects, provide an excellent opportunity to apply this knowledge in a collaborative setting, sharpening both your problem-solving and communication skills—critical tools for any healthcare professional. If you’re serious about becoming a thoughtful and well-rounded healthcare professional, this class is an invaluable experience.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I like that lectures are detailed and recorded for later review. I also really liked the grant writing because it is a skill that is helpful for most people pursuing STEM.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Newpher exceeded all of my expectations as a professor. I had been trying to get into one of his classes because of all the amazing things I had heard about him from peers and upperclassmen throughout my time as a neuro major at Duke, and was so fortunate to finally get a chance to take a class with him. I absolutely loved the predictability and organization of the course. The structure of lecture, team-based quiz, and application activity in this exact cycle with the mini mock-grant assignments that were sprinkled sporadically throughout the course of the entire semester allowed for such a positive learning environment. Not only were the two midterms not daunting because of this set-up but also it allowed for you to really engage with the course content and put low-pressure and low-stress emphasis on gaining a deep understanding of the grant project for which we had to propose for our semester long grant.

response_text: Teams should be kept. We were put in teams of 4 and led class discussions for 3 classes. Dr. Ng heavily encourages class participation, and she does a good job of doing so. The class is a comfortable environment. Research papers are the basis of our learning, and we have to write a discussion post for each paper. Then, we reply to classmates's posts. And finally, we discuss the papers in class. Doing all of this does take a few hours, but I learned a lot by reading other classmates' perspectives.

response_text: This course is very bio/neuro based, and I wouldn't take it if you're looking for a more psychology-oriented course. The content was familiar if you'd taken a neuro or bio class. Most people found this course really interesting, and Dr. Kuhn is very lax in her approach to teaching. I didn't care for the course because it was not as interesting as I'd thought, but that isn't to say that this course isn't great and informative for those passionate about this topic. The course was not difficult by any means, and I really enjoyed the variety in the assignments (paper, homework, in-class, take home exams, and group presentation). The amount of work required for this course definitely comes in waves. Sometimes there's a good amount of work when you have an exam, and other times you really have little to do for it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much about the immune system as well as neuroimmune interactions. I think the most important thing I learned was that the brain is not immune privileged like commonly thought. I also learned about how chronic stress has such negative health impacts, while acute stress can actually boost immune function. Lastly, I learned about CVOs, which are "leaky" regions of the blood brain barrier.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the field of neuroimmunology as a whole, that microglia are the immune cells of the brain and how they migrate to that region of the developing embryo, and how rabies virus has been one of the most influential and deadly zoonotic pathogen humans have faced for centuries.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It uses the same team-based learning structure that several other neuroscience professors (especially Dr Newpher) use in their classes. If you are interested in cell/molecular neuroscience, immunology, health/disease behaviors, or anything related you'll probably find this course interesting! Also, actually read the book Rabid when it's assigned- it's very interesting!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is so interesting! Make sure to do the work outside of class (the assigned readings before lecture and the scientific papers) and you are likely to do well. The class is team-based, but don't let that deter you--this structure is actually really helpful for the course and your teammates are some of your best resources.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

I have never been more fascinated in a class at Duke than I was in this one. Very interesting stuff.

response_text: I have never and will never be a fan of the flipped classroom. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to perform preprocessing steps for fMRI data analysis, the basic physics and mechanics of how an MRI machine works, and how to design an actual fMRI experiment, amongst many other things!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the practical, physical, and physiological principles underlying MRI and fMRI. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Overath was very supportive of his students and always made the effort to facilitate our learning in any way that he could. During lab, he would always take the time to check individually on each group and make sure that our progress was satisfactory. While the slides were often a bit dry, I did enjoy lectures and the labs were a good way to synthesize knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you think you are interested in brain imaging, take this course! You understand way more after taking it and will be much more useful to labs that do fmri.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very rewarding class that will provide you with useful skills for a career in cognitive research, but do not take it if you cannot commit time outside of class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Your work is cut out for you, but this class is definitely worthwhile if you give it the time it deserves.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! It's a grad school level class that you have the opportunity to take as an upperclassman undergrad. It's challenging and a lot of work and reading at times, but it is extremely fulfilling to learn everything you'd want to about the fMRI process. If you're looking for an easy A, this isn't the class unless you're willing to put the work in however. Dr. Overath is amazing however, and I enjoyed the class a ton and am glad I took it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Incredible course to learn about FMRI at great depth. Mix of lectures, lab and project allows us to apply concepts we learn and understand their practical relevance. Opportunity to design and conduct an FMRI study is a game changer. Overath is a great professor, very passionate about the topic but also his students and supporting them throughout the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take good notes during lecture because the slides are sometimes difficult to go back to and get material out of if you don't have information about figures written down

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is somewhat demanding, but it is very rewarding! And it was actually less demanding than I expected.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to conduct research with animal models, I was able to sharpen my skills to make analysis with scientific data, and I learned how to make good scientific figures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of methods relating to research with flies (fly husbandry, larval dissection, immunohistochemistry) as well as how to think critically how to design research projects to address questions. I also learned a lot about how to make good figure legends and figures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a much better sense of how work in the lab is done.  I think both Dr.O and Dr. Sheerwood did a great job of teaching the class how to operate a functional lab.  I learned how to keep my lab organized and orderly along with how to think more like someone who works in a lab.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have learned how to draft a successful scientific figure, how to manipulate data using R, and new methods of working with flies in the lab!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

background knowledge about AD-HSP diseases related lastest research

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors were always available to help and gave clear instructions. I really liked how we started each lab class with a powerpoint letting us know what we were going to be doing that day and recapping what we had done to put our next steps into perspective. This really helped keep the context in mind of what we were doing as the semester progressed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think they did a great job.  There was enough structure that I would succeed but also enough freedom where I would fail and learn from it.  If I ever needed help both professors were there to help me and resolve my problem.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved that we each had our individual stations and flies to take care of. We got to all do it ourselves, hands on, but in a setting where we were being instructed on how to do each step. I feel like I learned a ton in lab and it was the perfect balance of responsibility and guidance to help me figure out what working in a lab could be in the future.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned how to efficiently and adequately read scientific papers from a variety of topics. Not only did we learn how to read them, but we learned how to constructively criticize the papers, evaluating them based on their reliability - do we believe the results? Additionally, we learned to think in the future - what further experiments could be done? What does it make you wonder about? I majorly expanded my definition of the senses - I once believed there were only 5, but after taking this class I know about many different ways in which humans and animals sense the world.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The very first day of class, Professor Johnsen had us list out as many senses as we could think of, and then let us as a class choose which senses were most interesting to us. He then compiled scientific papers and in-class demos to allow us to explore these senses. Professor Johnsen really cares about what we want to learn, and has exposed us to a whole new world of senses. Additionally, he requires that each of us lead a class discussion once throughout this semester. This allows us to refine our scientific communication skills. Finally, because it is a seminar, it allows us to build close connections with each other and the teacher, encouraging active participation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read scientific papers efficiently and effectively, as well as about the major senses – who would have thought so many exist! Another skill I learned was how to brainstorm creative extensions for neuro studies. For example, we looked at a lot of pilot case studies or those involving a single patient.
