question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how critically evaluate papers and connect them to what we learned in class. Also how to create my own models and figures.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specific circuits and reading papers critically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the cellular and molecular underpinnings of disease processes such as Alzheimer's and fragile X syndrome and more broadly, of learning and memory. I learned how to read papers more in depth and analyze figures and to articulate findings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Retention of course content, presentation skills, critical thinking skills

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned how to dissect dense research papers and learn to understand the figures as well as complex neuro circuits and how they interact to cause behavior

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The time is took me to read and comprehend cellular neurobiology papers dropped enormously during this course. I also learned a great deal about the induction, stabilization, and consolidation of LTP.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned a great deal about the molecular and cellular mechanisms by which learning occurs. In terms of skills, this class has really honed my ability to read a jargon-heavy research article and be able to pick apart the important findings. I also learned how to effectively communicate figures through the journal club-esque application activities.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Mechanisms of memory formation and consolidation at the synaptic level- LTP induction, AMPAR trafficking, homeostatic plasticity, etc.
Mechanisms of motor learning and adaptation
How learning and memory are impacted in neurodegenerative and neurodevelopmental diseases and what neurobiological mechanisms may underly these processes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to incorporate knowledge from other Neuroscience lectures or seminars that apply to the topics we learned in this class.
2. I learned about the importance of sleep for memory in a deeper sense of the neurobiology of it, more than just knowing that it is important.
3. I learned further how to discuss scientific papers and extrapolate relevant data and findings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot in this course! I think one of the three biggest things I learned had to do with how to read scientific papers to get a clear understanding of the data presented. Another thing I learned was the importance of sleep for memory consolidation as well as the impact of stress on our memory (and how it can be both good and bad depending on when the stress occurs). Lastly I learned a lot about LTP and LTD and how both are required for adequate learning and memory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course I learned a detailed overview of how the brain works regarding learning and memory. I learned how to work better in a team, and I also believe that my reading of scientific papers improved due to the weekly readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about long term potentiation's role in memory formation, causes of neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's Disease and Fragile X, and lots of team-learning skills!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the most in-depth neuroscience course I have taken so far at Duke. It taught me about molecular mechanisms underlying learning and memory and made me practice reading and presenting important neuroscience papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how sleep affects memory. I learned about Alzheimer's. I learned about Fragile X. I learned how to read research papers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the structure of the course with weekly quizzes because it encouraged me to stay consistent with studying and to keep up with the material. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: it was helpful how small the class was and how we were held accountable for the information by being in a team. i really appreciate team based learning when its done well and Dr.Newpher does a really good job implementing it- also the module quizzes are great for keeping you on track

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the RATs were great for keeping me accountable. The lectures were also very engaging and well-constructed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was my first class with Dr. Newpher's 3 parts per module teaching style, and I absolutely loved it. The lecture days were naturally very information heavy, but it was always taught in a way that followed a logical flow and that was digestible. The individual and team components of both the quizzes and application activities really allowed me to understand the broader picture of the information that we learned, and I felt as if I was actually comprehending many of the details instead of just memorizing them. I also really enjoyed the access to past recorded lectures, which was very helpful if I missed a lecture day or just needed a slightly different explanation of a topic covered in class. I thought the content chosen overall was very relevant and followed a logical order.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The weekly quizzes are helpful and encourage consistent review
The team activities were designed well

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The team based learning works very well for Neuroscience seminar courses, and the best example of this is the team quizzes which allow conversation and thinking critically about the content you were just tested on in the individual section.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really like the overall structure of this course. I think TBL is a good strategy for students to really understand and work with the content at a pace that best suits them. It is really beneficial to be able to take quizzes alone and then with teammates to discuss responses and also the act of explaining your thought process leading to why you chose a specific response really aids in your learning and grasp of the course content. I also like that the course is structured in a way so that we get a lecture, get tested on our knowledge and understanding, and then apply what we have learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As in most of the neuroscience classes at Duke, the learning environment was very positive due to the team-based learning approach. I think that in this class specifically, Newpher did a great job at allowing us to get close with our teams and learn how to work with our teams which was very helpful and made for a comfortable and curious environment. I would keep the TBL structure, and I would keep the presentations during the APPs rather than just answering questions. I think the presentation allowed for the groups to have to work together more whereas the questions sometimes allows for people to remain quiet while the other people in the group answered them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really like the way Newpher set up this class! For each module, we have a day of lecture, a day of quizzes on the material, and a day of application activities. This format ensures that you keep on track with the material and that you truly understand it instead of just memorizing. The neurodegenerative/neurodevelopmental disorders unit and the invertebrate models of learning were my two favorite units.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Newpher is incredibly organized, and his structure makes the class a positive, fun, and welcoming learning environment. He is always eager to answer questions. I think we covered more ground content-wise by watching the video lectures before class, and I heavily relied on Dr. Newpher's pre-quiz recaps to help me sort through the most important information and clarify what I didn't understand. The team structure allowed me to practice explaining concepts and identify areas that I didn't understand. The learning objectives were very clear. I like that we do not have a cumulative exam because there is a LOT of material to memorize.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Newpher was a very supportive and encouraging professor. He was also willing to meet with students. He also was positive and made everyone feel like they could succeed in this class.I really liked the team based learning structure of this course. I think it is nice to work in a team and makes it more fun than just listening to lectures which often get boring for me as it is hard to focus for so long. Maybe lectures could be shorter and then do an activity after? I know this is complicated but perhaps something worth thinking about, however it seems other people have an easier time focusing for 75 min than I do.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class is usually stimulating because we vary the types of assignments we are doing, and I like that we have "journal club" style application activities to talk through papers such that everyone is involved. I did not love the motor learning module.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Very cool topics and great examples of experiments to demonstrate key concepts in lecture. I liked that we sometimes read research articles with competing findings and could debate it for ourselves. I liked the metaplasticity, sleep, and neurodegeneration lectures best.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I like how the topics were real concrete things that affect our life. Memory is very tangible topic and relevant to lives of students. I also enjoyed the team work. The frequent quizzes were sometimes annoying however I think they were so important to my keeping up with course content. Also, I think it is much better that the day of the quiz rotates rather than it always being Wednesday, for example, in the other class I took with Dr. Newpher. This levels the playing field and makes things more equitable in my opinion. Last time I had two quizzes on the same day every week and weekly EMT meetings the night before so I was never performing my best. Now the days vary and I am not much more overwhelmed than other students.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course as it covers a range of topics and really develops your understanding of common Neuroscience topics like LTP and cellular mechanisms of learning that a lot of the time seem very mysterious in nature.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend this course! Dr. Newpher is such a great professor and does a really good job of making the course content digestible. I recommend looking over the lecture slides before coming to class to help you stay focused since the lectures can be dense the first time through. This class is team based, so if you really aren't a fan I wouldn't encourage you to take this course, but if you are willing to give it (another) shot, it is very worth it. Your engagement with the course content will be reflected in your quiz and exam scores, so come to class prepared and ready to learn!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely take it if you are genuinely interested in neuroscience and the main topic of learning and memory. I think that taking a class with professor Newpher is something that is necessary as he is such a great teacher and really engages everyone in the class no matter what their background is.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Learning and memory are two of my favorite subjects in neuroscience, so this class was very engaging! You have to stay on top of your work because you have weekly quizzes, but if you pay attention to lecture and look over the notes a couple of times, you will be fine because the quizzes and tests are very fair. Newpher is very smart, so you learn a lot, but also he is very caring and willing to answer any questions that arise. I highly recommend this class to any person interested in neuroscience!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's in your best interests to watch the lectures before because then you can come into class and ask questions

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would say do not be fooled by the fact this course has a Psych code! It is entirely neuroscience! I am a bit confused why this could count as Psych. I understand it is about the mind but I feel it is much more bio. I might have thought twice before taking this as a last semester senior Psych major. It is like Dr. Newpher's other classes in terms of difficulty but I am a humanities word-oriented person and was hoping this would be more psych based than the other class I took with Dr. Newpher which was Bio and Neuro coded I think. This could have been avoided if I just talked to Dr. Newpher and asked but I wanted to take another course with him and was optimistic. Dr. Newpher is a great and enthusiastic professor who does a great job supporting students. He cares about teaching and wants students to really learn. The course is fair but I still think it is hard.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the neurobiology mechanisms for LTP and memory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Three specific things I learned are the molecular basis of memory, specifically pertaining to LTP and its stages, how motor learning occurs, and how sleep and stress affect memory and learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- thoroughly analyze research papers and know how to apply them to activities
- How to explain the current knowledge about the formation of memories
- How to aply what we have learned to other hypothetical questions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- biological basis of how memory is stored and formed within systems and cells
- engrams and memory consolidation/plasticity

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the details of LTP/LTD and their role in memory formation, about homeostatic plasticity, motor learning, about disorders like Alzheimer's and Fragile X syndrome, and the list goes on.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed an extensive knowledge of learning and memory at the cellular and molecular level. I gained an appreciation for the extensive machinery involved in different types of learning and where in the brain this is all occurring. I developed better note taking strategies as a result of staying engaged during lecture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had to develop a strong sense of analyzing research and being able to take that information and apply it. The course content was very detailed, so I also learned to memorize by being able to walk through a process.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: From this course, I mainly expanded my knowledge on how memory is formed and strenghted in the cell. I learned the interplay of intracelluar mechanisma and intercellular mechanisms that help in memeory formatin. For example, I learned the importance of NMDAR receptors and AMPAR receptors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the cellular and molecular mechanisms behind different forms of memory. I learned about the combination of genetics and environment that create learned behavior. I learned about dysfunction in learning and memory and disease states that impact these processes. I learned how to better understand scientific writing and research papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got to learn new ways for myself about going through learning and stress, which was great and very applicable to the situation of school. I also got to learn more in-depth neurobiological mechanisms for how memories are created and consolidated. Finally I got to learn about a lot of applications for memory in ways which I might not have explicitly thought of in life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: differentiating the role of AMPAR vs NMDARs in memory systems, understanding the role of ARC and its diverse roles in memory consolidation, understanding memory in the context of mice experiments

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A much better understanding of the neuroscience of memory and learning, diseases associated with these pathways, experiments and protocols that are commonly used in learning-related neuroscience research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to work with a group productively and efficiently because we would often have to create presentations of answer APP questions in a single class period which motivated us to work together and use each others strengths. I learned a lot about the course content and by recalling content for the quiz and then again for the exam I think it will help me retain the information for a long time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to connect all the steps and components of long-term potentiation on a cellular level. I also learned how to summarize relevant neurobiology literature, discuss my findings with a group, and present to the class. I learned that Arc is one of the most important proteins in our bodies, and it has a dual function in synaptic plasticity that makes it so interesting to learn about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about invertebrate model systems used in neuroscience research, learning and memory, signaling pathways, how different proteins and mechanisms are involved in memory consolidation, homeostatic plasticity, and sleep, stress, and memory (which was probably my favorite topic).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The lectures were clear, and the quizzes helped reinforce material.

response_text: The TBL model of this class really keeps you on top of the material, and Dr. Newpher is an expert at implementing it in a effective manner.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: - teamed based learning is a great model for the class, allows people of all different learning styles to succeed and understand the material

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed having both lecture in class and having recordings available and the flow of the class alternating between lecture, then iRAs, tRAs, and then APPs. Kept the course very engaging and felt like I learned a lot more through this format.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The TBL set-up, engagement with academic literature in groups, + easy-to-understand and engaging delivery of lectures really made this course great

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Newpher's class structure is very student-friendly, and this being my 2nd class with him, I appreciate the module structure of weekly quizzes and group work to be very rewarding and beneficial to my learning. I honestly would not change a thing.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The team based activities were a great way to have classmates interact with each other and reflect on their learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the team activities are a great way to learn the material . I feel like the lectures can sometimes become an information overload, but the team activites force me to actually think about the logic of what we lrarned in a application sense.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instruction format (lecture followed by individual quiz, then re-taking the same quiz with your team, and then going over that quiz) for new material is very effective in my opinion. You have many opportunities to solidify your understanding prior to any midterms. The information is broken up into units that are logical and more easy to grasp. The readings that relate to each unit are made easy to understand through team application activities. The recorded lectures in addition to in person lecturing allow you to revisit any material that is confusing at any time. I would keep the same format.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I have always loved and appreciated Dr.Newpher's style of teaching, and you can really tell that it is based in cognitive research behind how people learn best. I appreciate how every day in a unit is different so that you never really get bored and you get to learn/think about the topics in 3 unique ways (lecture, quizzes, and research papers!). I also have to say I really like the split method of doing some research papers as group presentations and some as actual write-up activities.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thoroughly enjoyed the group learning activity---cool to see the immediate application from what we learned in the lesson before

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The in person lecture and the recorded lectures online was super helpful. It exposed us to the content early, but then allowed us to go back and review as needed before quizzes. I liked the quizzes too, it made studying for the exams a lot easier.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I knew what the structure of this course would be going into it and I personally like the pattern of lecture, quiz, group activities. However, some of the lectures do incorporate a lot of information so some people may prefer more time being devoted to the course content but I personally enjoyed the structure and learning environment. I think without the quizzes it would honestly be hard to stay up to date on the material and the quizzes are a good way to check in and make sure you understand the material before moving to a group activity.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love that this course followed a pattern of lecture, then quiz, and then group activity. This formula helped me learn more about each component of our topics in different ways. I also really like the team-based aspect of this course. It allowed me to connect with other neuro and biology students, and we were able to enhance one another's understanding. Everyone was so collaborative and found ways to pitch in or "carry" the group at different points in the semester. I think the team-based aspect and in-person lectures should absolutely be kept in the future.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Newpher is a professor who really cares about his students and their learning, and it is evident to anyone right away when taking a class with him. The way he structures the class, although slightly unconventional compared to other college courses, facilitates learning and ensures we actually learn the material and not just memorize it for an exam and then proceed to forget it right away. He plans the course so that there is one day for the lecture on the current module, the next class we take a small quiz (first on our own and then in teams), and then the next class, to wrap up the module, we do a team application activity that is relevant for the module content. This forced me to stay on top of my studies throughout the semester and engage with the content as we went rather than leave stuff until the last minute. Dr. Newpher also does a very good job of creating a welcoming learning environment where we can ask questions and have discussions on the topics at hand without fear of judgment.

response_text: The subject material is very enganging and interesting, so the class is inherently stimulating if you actually take the time to learn the material; however, I think often times my brain turned off in lecture because there was just Too mich information in little time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Some of the material overlaps with other neuroscience courses on learning, memory, disease, etc. and felt redundant. A more clear progression or delineation between classes could be established.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really love that there is always such a good blend of strengthening prior concepts that we have learned in cognitive neuroscience or cell/molecular neurobiology in combination with new unique and specific topics to the course. Sometimes I will get a bit lost in parts of the lectures and I think that once you get lost once it can be more difficult to hop back on the lecture train, but I am currently unsure of ideas that would help that!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: every week, the content felt new enough to not feel repetetive but also tied back to prior lectures, which was beneficial

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content was the right amount of challenging. It was interesting and I learned a lot, but wasn’t impossible.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Whether it was through the APPs or just a few slides during lecture discussing interesting experiments, those were the most intellectually stimulating parts of the class to me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The content connected so well to Bio 223 and other neuro classes, and it filled in a lot of gaps about memory and learning that I had never considered before. The papers were very fascinating, and I appreciate how well they connected to each module.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I found this course very intellectually stimulating, but if I had to suggest anything that could maybe add to the course it would be to add more discussion on the current state of knowledge/research on the topics covered (i.e., whether the stuff we are looking at is at a point that it does not need more investigation because it's well-characterized enough or, if it is not in this stage yet, then what is being done right now to further investigations, and what can/needs to be done to get the information we need to draw complete and accurate conclusions).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The course is organized into modules, in which each module has a lecture, quiz, and application activity. The material is less difficult compared to Neuro223.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great senior seminar type of class. It is not difficult, but still engaging so you will learn a lot. There are exams and almost weekly quizzes, but paying attention during lecture many times will be enough for studying.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As a neuro, you should take any class with Newpher at your earliest opportunity, but especially this one. Really great engagement with such cool material

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a great one to take during your senior year. Take this course if you want to learn about this particular topic!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a decent amount of work, with long readings and weekly summaries of 800 words. The topic is really interesting and you learn a lot. Dr. Yin is very knowledgeable in the field, so I would recommend taking the class if you are interested in behavior. The ideas you learn about in this class are applicable across a wide range of fields, from neuroscience and behavior to computer science and engineering. Don't take this class if you are looking for an easy seminar, but it is a good class to take if you are genuinely interested in behavioral sciences. I think it is super doable to get an A, but you do have to engage a significant amount with the course to get one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to apply knowledge of psychopathology to critically evaluate depictions of disorders in films. 
2) I learned how to analyze a film from the unique standpoint of considering its relation to scientific facts about mental disorders. 
3) I developed skills in comparing depictions of psychopathology across different films and sharing ideas in productive discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Applying the knowledge of the last 3 years of Neuroscience education to modern day society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how the media portrayal of mental health impacts how we as consumers think of those conditions. I learned how honest and realistic representations of addiction help people see the struggles that come along with substance abuse and recovery. I learned that oftentimes schizophrenia is misrepresented in the media because it is more appealing to audiences to have visual hallucinations, while those are actually extremely uncommon in individuals with the condition. I also learned that depictions of DID usually include violence toward others, which is also rare in individuals with the conditions. I think the biggest takeaway I had from this course was to be more critical of the media in portraying mental health conditions because those representations can be harmful when inaccurate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze the depiction of mental illness in film through different time periods.  I learned about realistic versus dramaticized film depictions of mental illness look like.  I learned to think critically about the depiction of characters and mental illness in the plot of a movie.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different ways of thinking about the relationship between mental illness and the way it is portrayed in the media

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- A variety of knowledge about the experience of different disorders
- Especially in the DID week, critiquing the representations of disorders in media
- We were joined in class two times by different experts, a therapist and an in-patient psychiatrist, which taught a lot about treatment. Q&A with these experts was really eye-opening

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the relaxed environment that was created in the classroom - every class was truly fun because it just felt like a bunch of friends who wanted to discuss movies they had seen. In our class discussions, there was an excellent balance of making sure everyone had the chance to speak by going around in a circle, while still allowing flexibility and having people chime in even when it wasn't their "turn." Dr. Hariri does a great job of making the conversation flow and building off of students' comments on the films - even though the class was two and a half hours, it never felt like it dragged on!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr Hariri is the perfect professor for this class. He's very welcoming, funny, and friendly, and very knowledgeable about the topics. I can confidently say that throughout my entire education, elementary school, middle school, high school, college, Dr Hariri is my favorite professor. A lot of the movies approach some very difficult topics, and Dr Hariri guides discussion expertly, addressing the topics but maintaining a light-hearted atmosphere.The structure was perfect. It was weekly seminars discussing a set of 2-3 movies centered on a disorder or associated topic such as institutionalization or therapy.It's one thing to read about a disorder in a textbook, but movies provide a more intimate understanding of the experience. An added layer of movies is the occasional poor representation of a disorder, which creates even more discussion about the experience. In my opinion, movies are a lot more engaging than a textbook. And that engagement got me to research each topic more on my own time. Perfect setup.As a senior neuro major, I have a very strong interest in psychopathology, and that interest is really allowed to shine without the grading stress that comes from exams. I can focus on engaging with the topics that really matter to me, rather than worrying about what might show up on an exam. The structure was perfect.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I furthermore learned how to use NEURON and how to create simplified models to test the efficacy of neuroprosthetic systems. I also gained an insight into the broad spectrum of available neuroprosthetic, what the state of the industry is, and what the challenges in each field are.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Low-level, mid-level, and high-level neuronal circuitry and theory relating to movement.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Learned about the fundamentals of muscles and how various parts of the nervous system are involved in coordinating them for movement, and how different diseases affect their functioning.
2) Learned about the various functional units involved in higher order control of movement and the different functional deficits when things go wrong.
3) Learned about the population coding of movement in cortical neurons and how they can be used to develop brain-machine interfaces that could help the disabled.

response_text: I really love this course. Dr. Sommer is very helpful both in class and after class. When we have question, he is always willing to answer. The TA is also very helpful, she is able to help us by sending what we should do by email. No specific methods or components I could mention, but I think this course is well designed.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Sommer is an incredibly thoughtful and organized professor who presents course content in a clear and accessible manner and encourages deep learning beyond just memorization by sharing relevant research papers and offering both high-level overviews and detailed explanations to contextualize concepts within a broader framework. I really appreciate that he shares his lecture slides and recordings, which not only support review after class but also allow students to revisit material they may have missed. Many of my teachers avoid sharing these resources, likely as a way to encourage attendance, but Dr. Sommer's lectures are so engaging and informative that students want to go to class, and being able to review content afterward only enhances the learning experience and helps me achieve a deeper understanding. I also enjoy that he incorporates a variety of learning modalities—coding, reading primary literature, exploring both historical context and detailed anatomical content—which keeps the material dynamic and intellectually stimulating. Although the use of pop quizzes would typically not seem favorable, I found the way he implements them very positive and successful in encouraging me to consistently review notes, while his flexibility in offering partial and extra credit shows his genuine commitment to student success and learning. Overall, Dr. Sommer is an amazing and thoughtful professor and his dedication to both student learning and well-being is evident in every aspect of his teaching.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course touches on the foundations of neuroscience research and neuroimaging, with a particular focus on cognitive reserve. To understand the research, knowledge of how fMRI, EEG, MEG, and CSM were taught, as well as foundational principles like the basis of resting state fMRI and a multimodal theory of the brain. The course also delved into some linguistic theory and conversations about language and consciousness, as well as music and musicianship. A lot of the neuroscience research that we looked at was situated in the context of languaging and musicianship.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class gave me access to a lot of readings that taught me a bunch about how mental illness was viewed previously. In particular we discussed how medication like Prozac was targeted towards women previously to decrease their "irrational behavior," how asylums and in-patient treatment varied as time went on, and how the mechanisms of mental illness are still unclear to many people today.

response_text:
1. The course taught me the importance and value of learning the how of critique. I sometimes feel graduate level classes can be overly critical without paying enough attention to the why and how of critique but this course taught me that the question of why and how are equally important to critique and I liked that we used some primary texts too.
2. I liked the design of the classes and the way the instructor taught left no room for misunderstanding of the texts. Because the first half of the class is lecture style, this made the discussion half of the class rooted in materials used in the class itself.
3. I gained a thorough understanding of the history of mental illness in a way that challenged my thinking about the topic before. Eg: I had always been critical of psychiatry but this course gave me the tools and language on why I am critical of psychiatry. It also challenged my own assumptions about psychiatry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1.i'm new to historical approach and i think it has been very helpful for me to learn to think about the emergence of specific diagnostic categories in relation to the professionalization of psychiatry in specific historical and cultural contexts.  
2. i've learned to ask what instrumental value a diagnostic category has and reverse engineering the image of mental illness to deduce the picture of normality at that specific time — and ask why were these norms the norms being valued 
3.i've developed more understanding of the relationship between mental illness, capitalism, and health. I've learnt more about how to critically interrogate a diagnostic category from an economic and materialist perspective 
4. how to have conversations across disciplines

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to connect historical events as they relate to mental health institutions over about 4 centuries. More broadly, I learned how to view the development of an idea, institution, or whatever in the context of its historical causes and effects.
2. I learned how to articulate the connections from one piece of writing to another piece of writing of the same overall content.
3. I learned how to think critically about abstract topics in ways that doesn't reduce them down to a simple explanation (as abstract/complex problems seldom have simple solutions), and I improved in my ability to formulate questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of the field of psychiatry through contemporary articles and firsthand accounts. I learned about the changes and continuities in western conceptions of mental illness. I learned how the political landscape shaped the prominence of psychiatry in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class truly taught me how to think like a scientist, write an FDA drug application, present scientific findings, and be a better teammate and listener. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course provided me with a deeper and more holistic understanding of the complexities involved in drug development and treatment. Professor Sawyer did an exceptional job of teaching us not just the biological mechanisms of how drugs work, but also the various biological, physiological, ethical, and societal factors that must be considered when developing and administering treatments. Her approach emphasized that the development of drugs is not just about scientific discovery but also about understanding their real-world impact, including considerations of access, safety, and patient care. This broader perspective helped me appreciate the intricate balance between efficacy and the diverse ethical and practical issues involved in drug therapies.
One of the most valuable skills I developed was the ability to research and write a comprehensive report on a drug's effectiveness, particularly in relation to a specific medical issue, such as vasculitis. I had the opportunity to explore why current treatments were ineffective and collaborate with my peers to propose novel drug solutions. This hands-on project pushed me to think critically about treatment limitations and how to improve them. The experience of designing a clinical trial for the drug was particularly enlightening. It gave me valuable insight into the complex processes of trial design, including identifying variables, ensuring patient safety, and navigating ethical concerns. This knowledge is something I would not have gained without the course and will be essential in my future as a physician.
Perhaps the most profound insight I gained was understanding how drugs affect biological processes and why certain drugs work for some patients but not for others. This realization highlighted the importance of personalized medicine, where treatment plans are tailored to the unique genetic, environmental, and physiological factors of each patient. I now appreciate that drug development and administration are not one-size-fits-all solutions. Instead, they require a humanistic and comprehensive approach that takes into account the full complexity of the patient. This way of thinking—focused on patient individuality and the variability of biological responses—will inform my approach to patient care, ensuring I treat people as whole individuals rather than as cases or conditions to be managed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how drugs are metabolized by the body and how different factors (i.e. physical or genetic) can cause differences across humans. I learned about the process of getting a drug approved. I learned about the chemical and kinetic mechanism of action for many different kinds of drugs. I learned about the barriers of drug design and production.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the semester-long project about designing a drug from conception to clinical trials. I liked how I was able to use my imagination, curiosity, and knowledge from previous classes to do the project. It would be really cool if I saw this drug being made in the future. I also liked the concept of the biweekly quizzes compared to larger tests, since they were more digestable. The grading and organization of the class was good in terms of number of assignments. Dr. Sawyer was also an amazing professor and was able to meet outside of class whenever I needed help with brainstorming or class content. The slides were also generally useful to review later on, and the lectures were very organized. I really liked the 3 assignments we did, especially the last one. I also really liked the in-class activities, since they increased my engagement with the content significantly. I would not change the in-class activities.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The structure and components of this course created an ideal learning environment that blended traditional instruction with active, collaborative learning. I particularly appreciated the balance between didactic lectures, where we were introduced to new information, and the group activities that encouraged us to engage directly with real-world problems. This dual approach allowed me to not only absorb the material but also to apply it in meaningful ways. Working on group projects, especially those addressing real-life issues, made the theoretical concepts we discussed in class feel relevant and tangible. The combination of learning new concepts and immediately using them to think critically and develop solutions was incredibly effective, solidifying my understanding in a way that simply listening to lectures could not have done.
One memorable example of this was the fun in-class activities, like the Halloween project, where we worked in teams to research a topic and present our findings to the class. This was not just an opportunity to deepen our knowledge, but also a chance to develop important skills in teamwork and public speaking. Learning to communicate complex information clearly and effectively is an essential skill in any field, and the experience of presenting to peers in a structured, supportive environment gave me a valuable opportunity to hone this skill. These interactive components, which emphasized collaboration and communication, are aspects of the course I would certainly recommend keeping in future iterations. They contributed to an engaging and dynamic classroom experience that was both intellectually stimulating and personally rewarding.
However, as effective as the course structure and activities were, it was Professor Sawyer’s teaching style and personal example that truly made the learning environment exceptional. She brought a calm, positive energy to every class, fostering an atmosphere where intellectual curiosity thrived. Her respectful and empathetic approach to teaching made me feel seen and heard, allowing me to ask questions and express doubts after class and engage deeply with the material. More than just imparting knowledge, she embodied the values of thoughtfulness, compassion, and ethical integrity. These qualities inspired me to approach learning and, ultimately, my future career with a sense of purpose and responsibility. Professor Sawyer’s influence went far beyond her role as a lecturer; she set a standard for how to teach with care, passion, and respect for students, and I believe that future students will benefit not only from the course’s content and structure but from her example as a role model.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would absolutely say to take this course. Dr. Sawyer is a great professor who cares about her students and wants them to do well. The group project is manageable and interesting, and there are many points throughout this class to pursue your specific interest within pharmacology. Dr. Sawyer is very accepting of student feedback and she will work with everyone to meet expectations for the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I recommend the class. The semester-long project is challenging but definitely worth taking the course for. This project has inspired me to do pharmacology in the future. It is a very fast-paced and assignment-heavy course, however, so be prepared.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you're considering taking this course, I highly recommend it. It offers a unique and comprehensive perspective on pharmacology, covering not just the biological and physiological mechanisms of drugs, but also the ethical, societal, and personal considerations that are essential for anyone pursuing a career in healthcare. As future prescribers of medication, understanding how drugs work in the body, the limitations of current treatments, and the complexities of individualized care is vital. This course goes beyond textbook knowledge—it encourages you to think critically about real-world issues, such as why certain treatments may not work for all patients and how to design drugs and clinical trials that can address these disparities. The hands-on activities, particularly the group projects, provide an excellent opportunity to apply this knowledge in a collaborative setting, sharpening both your problem-solving and communication skills—critical tools for any healthcare professional. If you’re serious about becoming a thoughtful and well-rounded healthcare professional, this class is an invaluable experience.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course! You will be amazed at how much you learn. The course isn't easy, but if you put in a good-faith effort, you will succeed and receive a grade that you are proud of.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: the class and the content is really interesting. be aware that here is a pretty huge, semester-long group project that, at times, has a major major workload and is fairly challenging. I'd still recommend it, you'll learn a lot and outside of the group project the workload is really nice (no exams)

response_text: This course is very bio/neuro based, and I wouldn't take it if you're looking for a more psychology-oriented course. The content was familiar if you'd taken a neuro or bio class. Most people found this course really interesting, and Dr. Kuhn is very lax in her approach to teaching. I didn't care for the course because it was not as interesting as I'd thought, but that isn't to say that this course isn't great and informative for those passionate about this topic. The course was not difficult by any means, and I really enjoyed the variety in the assignments (paper, homework, in-class, take home exams, and group presentation). The amount of work required for this course definitely comes in waves. Sometimes there's a good amount of work when you have an exam, and other times you really have little to do for it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of neuroscience (Aristotle, ventricular doctrine...), whether the brain can be functionally localized, lesion studies and brain function, brain area, fMRI controversies, reductionism, the brain as a computer, the Marr framework, mechanistic explanations of neuroscience, memory, consciousness, and free will among other topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
1) A lot about the history of psychology and neuroscience, how they intersected and are undergirded by philosophy, and the origins of a lot of the ideas about the brain we have today
2) To think more critically about neuroscientific methods, considering the limitations of different instruments and other methodological approaches
3) A lot more about some foundational neuroscience and psychology case studies that I have heard of but not engaged with nearly as critically as we did here

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned a lot about the different circuits in the brain and I didn't realize how the parts of the brain were connected before. In particular, we learned about how the dlPFC is the hub of the corticohippocampal circuit which contributes to disorders that cause dysfunctions in executive control. They can lead to schizophrenia, substance use disorder and OCD.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about circuits in the brain that affect disorders through anatomy of the brain, what circuits represent order in the brain, and what circuits look like when there is disorder in the brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the current neuroscientific understanding of how neural circuits and processes integrate to develop order and disorder in response to threat (recognition/reaction - corticolimbic circuit), goal-directed behavior (motivation/action - corticostriatal circuit), and higher order processing (executive control/memory - corticohippocampal circuit).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! It's a grad school level class that you have the opportunity to take as an upperclassman undergrad. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how changes in the endocrine system lead to a lot of common cognitive and behavioral disorders. I also learned that the HPA axis is at the center of these disorders. Then finally, I learned about some current therapeutic interventions that could help alleviate behavioral disorders by targeting specific hormones and neural pathways.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about hormones in the body, how neuroscience intersects with endocrinology, and how to iteratively write a scientific paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One of the main skills I learned this semester was reading scientific papers. I think I improved my ability to parse information with lots of jargon. I also learned alot about my topic surrounding testosterone and risk taking. I learned about the different brain regions involved in risk/reward and how testosterone influences these regions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: More concrete speaking and writing skills related to professional literature in neuroscience, as well as thinking about how to have a productive conversation about these topics and their future. Also learned a lot about hormonal differences in neurological disease, which relates to sex frequently.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We developed many skills in this course, but I think the most important ones were learning how to read, digest, and present research information. Whether that was presenting an assigned figure from the assigned reading or presenting our individual semester-long research, Dr. Mchenry did a wonderful job of allowing us to explain research in our way, allowing us to ask questions, giving us constructive feedback, and guiding us towards really helpful practices that we can use in the future

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I didn't know much about endocrinology before taking this class, and I underestimated the challenges associated with neuroendocrine research. I definitely have a much greater appreciation for the complexities involved in this research and a much better understanding of how hormones interact with the nervous system. This class helped me to think of problems in a new way and develop strategies to connect the dots when faced with many unknowns. I think neuroendocrinology is a great subject to use to develop those skills, because there are so many unknowns, but also everything is so interconnected.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Basic understanding of neuroendocrinology, and exposure to a vast and sufficiently challenging amount of the existing literature within the field.

response_text: This course is a decent amount of work, with long readings and weekly summaries of 800 words. The topic is really interesting and you learn a lot. The ideas you learn about in this class are applicable across a wide range of fields, from neuroscience and behavior to computer science and engineering. Don't take this class if you are looking for an easy seminar, but it is a good class to take if you are genuinely interested in behavioral sciences. I think it is super doable to get an A, but you do have to engage a significant amount with the course to get one.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how to apply knowledge of psychopathology to critically evaluate depictions of disorders in films. 
2) I learned how to analyze a film from the unique standpoint of considering its relation to scientific facts about mental disorders. 
3) I developed skills in comparing depictions of psychopathology across different films and sharing ideas in productive discussions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1 - how to critique the implications of how the depiction of mental illness in movies leads to perceptions in society
2 - biological basis of mental illness
3 - decipher between accurate representations of illness versus dramatization

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Applying the knowledge of the last 3 years of Neuroscience education to modern day society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about how the media portrayal of mental health impacts how we as consumers think of those conditions. I learned how honest and realistic representations of addiction help people see the struggles that come along with substance abuse and recovery. I learned that oftentimes schizophrenia is misrepresented in the media because it is more appealing to audiences to have visual hallucinations, while those are actually extremely uncommon in individuals with the condition. I also learned that depictions of DID usually include violence toward others, which is also rare in individuals with the conditions. I think the biggest takeaway I had from this course was to be more critical of the media in portraying mental health conditions because those representations can be harmful when inaccurate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze the depiction of mental illness in film through different time periods.  I learned about realistic versus dramaticized film depictions of mental illness look like.  I learned to think critically about the depiction of characters and mental illness in the plot of a movie.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Different ways of thinking about the relationship between mental illness and the way it is portrayed in the media

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- A variety of knowledge about the experience of different disorders
- Especially in the DID week, critiquing the representations of disorders in media
- We were joined in class two times by different experts, a therapist and an in-patient psychiatrist, which taught a lot about treatment. Q&A with these experts was really eye-opening

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the relaxed environment that was created in the classroom - every class was truly fun because it just felt like a bunch of friends who wanted to discuss movies they had seen. In our class discussions, there was an excellent balance of making sure everyone had the chance to speak by going around in a circle, while still allowing flexibility and having people chime in even when it wasn't their "turn." Dr. Hariri does a great job of making the conversation flow and building off of students' comments on the films - even though the class was two and a half hours, it never felt like it dragged on!

I also appreciated Dr.Hariris facilitation of discussion and helping us all learn.  I also liked that everyone got their chance to speak in class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr Hariri is the perfect professor for this class. He's very welcoming, funny, and friendly, and very knowledgeable about the topics. I can confidently say that throughout my entire education, elementary school, middle school, high school, college, Dr Hariri is my favorite professor. A lot of the movies approach some very difficult topics, and Dr Hariri guides discussion expertly, addressing the topics but maintaining a light-hearted atmosphere.The structure was perfect. It was weekly seminars discussing a set of 2-3 movies centered on a disorder or associated topic such as institutionalization or therapy.It's one thing to read about a disorder in a textbook, but movies provide a more intimate understanding of the experience. An added layer of movies is the occasional poor representation of a disorder, which creates even more discussion about the experience. In my opinion, movies are a lot more engaging than a textbook. And that engagement got me to research each topic more on my own time. Perfect setup.As a senior neuro major, I have a very strong interest in psychopathology, and that interest is really allowed to shine without the grading stress that comes from exams. I can focus on engaging with the topics that really matter to me, rather than worrying about what might show up on an exam. The structure was perfect.
